(Financial Framework Legislation Amendment Bill 2004) Mr Hunt to present a bill for an act to provide for water efficiency labelling and the making of water efficiency standards, and for Tuesday, 30 November 2004 ----Second Reading Debate resumed from 17 November, on motion by Mr Hardgrave: That the bill be now read a second time. Ms MACKLIN (Jagajaga) (4.30 p.m.)-The Howard government has well and truly failed the skills test. The Howard government’s inaction has seen a severe skills shortage develop on its watch, which is hurting Australian business, families and our economy. Skills, as a driver of productivity, have dropped a staggering 75 per cent over the last 10 years, a shocking record from this government. We now have severe skills shortages in key trades and industries-engineers, electricians, mechanics, bricklayers, plumbers and metal fitters-and in the service industries, especially child care and aged care. The Productivity Commission has found that Australia needs more skilled workers and more skills growth to address skills shortages, improve living standards and remain internationally competitive, yet tens of thousands of Australians are turned away from TAFE each year because this government will not fund enough TAFE places. Most of the growth in the New Apprenticeships scheme over the last few years has happened in areas where there are no skills shortages. One study has found that between 20 and 30 per cent of new apprentices receive inadequate training, and about half the people who do not finish their new apprenticeships say it is because they feel they are being used as cheap labour instead of being trained. The Australian Industry Group has found that, across the manufacturing sector-right now, not in four years time-there are between 18,000 and 21,000 unfilled vacancies for tradespeople. What is more, according to the Australian Industry Group the number of traditional apprenticeships has remained largely unchanged since this government came into office in 1996. Just last week there was more bad news. According to the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations skilled vacancy index, vacancies for skilled tradespersons have increased by a staggering 54 per cent over the last three years. The figures reveal sharply rising demand for skilled workers in the key areas of metal trades, automotive, electrical and construction industries. Other figures last week confirmed that the Howard government is doing little to address this demand. According to the latest figures from the National Centre for Vocational Education and Research, there has been a massive 22 per cent drop in the share of apprenticeships in traditional trades since 1999. Only one in three apprenticeships were in training in the traditional trades fields for the June quarter this year, compared to 42 per cent five years earlier. What a shocking record. The NCVER figures also reveal that over the 12 months to June 2004 the number of Australians commencing a traineeship or apprenticeship has dropped 10 per cent, with nearly 30,000 fewer people having commenced training compared to the 12 months to June 2003. There are 9,800 fewer people in training, according to this report. The number of people cancelling or withdrawing from training is up by 5,400 compared to the June 2003 quarter, a jump of 19 per cent. These are the actual figures of what has been happening in vocational MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Ramus Scholarships Alone That Is A Very Schedule Fee Of Bulk Billed Consultations

speaker: The Deputy Speaker (Hon. I.r. Causley) Took The Chair At 4.30 P.m.
theText: education and training under this government. You would think it would be a wake-up call. After eight years, what a mess they have created. They have let a severe skills shortage develop, and they are doing next to nothing to address it. It is, of course, Australian business and families that have to pay the price for the government’s lack of action. Yesterday, we saw a very confused Minister for Vocational and Technical Education reveal that he is well and truly out of his depth. He has no understanding of the seriousness of the severe skills crisis that has developed on this government’s watch. In answer to a question from the federal member for Adelaide about whether the Howard government supported industry levies to deal with the acute national skills shortage, the minister replied that, no, he does not support industry levies. The minister clearly has no idea that earlier this month the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission authorised an industry levy on bricks to fund more apprenticeships in order to address a shortage of skilled bricklayers. The government’s inaction has led to the industry having to put a levy on to pay for increased training. The minister responded with what can only be described as confused waffle when I asked him-in light of his answer-what he was going to do to stop this new levy on Australian families and businesses. The minister’s answer was that the issue was not within his remit. It just shows that the minister either does not know or does not care that Australia’s skills shortage is seriously hurting. Amazingly, the minister also put his stamp of approval on increased costs for families and businesses arising from the wage pressures caused by Australia’s skills shortage. He should of course tell that to local business and families, who are struggling to cope with spiralling costs because of the skills shortage that has happened on this government’s watch. On the site of the new terminal at Adelaide airport, the shortage of wall and ceiling fixers is so severe that GMR Interiors, one of the construction companies on site, has to pay up to $600 a week above the industry rate. But the minister does not seem to care about this. Yesterday he said that inflated wages were a good thing, yet the severe skills shortage is clearly jeopardising local industry projects through inflated wages and costs. Local businesses across the country are giving away work because they cannot find enough workers to fulfil demand. And things are set to get worse and worse. According to the Australian Industry Group, right now Australia has a shortage of around 20,000 skilled workers in sectors like carpentry, construction, manufacturing and mining. The AIG says that over the next five years 175,000 people are expected to leave the traditional trades but only 70,000 are likely to enter. That means there will be a shortfall of more than 100,000 skilled workers. But what is the government doing to address this? We are looking at a shortage of 100,000 workers and what do we get from this government? Next to nothing-a handful of technical colleges that are frankly going to make barely a dent. These technical colleges will not start for another year, they will not be in place fully for four years and they will in fact only affect a tiny proportion of school students when they are in place. The skills crisis in this country is here and now and it is growing. Businesses cannot wait another year for action from the Howard government. They are crying out for more skilled workers right now. The colleges will provide training to fewer than two per cent of Australian year 11 and 12 students-that is the contribution they are going to make. The vast majority of senior secondary students will in fact miss out. Early school leavers and year 12 graduates will be excluded from the colleges, and yet every year under this government we turn away 40,000 Australians from TAFE and 40,000 early school leavers join the unemployment queue. MAIN COMMITTEE If this government invested the funds it is using for technical colleges into our TAFEs right now, we could create more than 45,000 desperately needed new places. Instead of wasting millions of dollars duplicating Australian TAFEs and limiting new training to just a few, the Howard government should fund our TAFEs properly and invest in more apprenticeships in areas of skills shortage. But instead of acting to address our skills shortages in this way the government is more interested in playing politics, especially with the states. The government has refused to fund any new TAFE places, and this has gone on for quite a considerable period of time. As can be seen, the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 that we are debating here today continues this neglect. It is further evidence of the government’s inaction on skill shortages. The bill reduces and limits the funding to the vocational education and training sector. The first section of the bill will reduce the level of funds for vocational education provided to the Australian National Training Authority for distribution to the states and territories in 2004. The funding will fall from $1.36 billion to $1.31 billion-once again, a reflection of this government’s failure to strike an agreement on training funding with the states and territories in the last round of ANTA negotiations. The bill will also appropriate up to $1.154 billion in funds for vocational education and training to be distributed by the states and territories for 2005. This amount of money, I have to say, is a stark reminder that the government cannot be trusted when it comes to education and training. While on the surface it sounds like a large amount, closer scrutiny reveals a system which has been starved of funds and is struggling to fill a gaping hole that was in fact created by this government when it first came to power. Just how little value this government places on training and apprenticeships was revealed when it slashed $240 million out of the VET sector in its first two budgets. This was swiftly followed by the 1998-2000 ANTA agreement, which abolished growth funding altogether and froze funding to the sector for the next three years. These funding cuts and the subsequent freeze have meant that more and more TAFE colleges have had to close some of their training facilities, putting teachers and students under pressure, and have threatened the quality in training and skills development in this country. At the same time that the government has been cutting and freezing funds we have had businesses crying out for more skilled staff, and of course there is a major shortage of TAFE places. This is the direct result of the Howard government’s education and training policies. This skills shortage has happened under this government’s watch. No-one else is to blame. This bill is just the latest instalment in a long-running saga surrounding the last ANTA agreement. So, instead of a government that approaches negotiations over the funding of our national training system as an opportunity to work with the states and territories, what we have is a government that just wants to play politics, buck-pass responsibility for its policy failings and, as usual, blame somebody else. No wonder the government has announced that it will close down the Australian National Training Authority. This authority was the vehicle to enable people to work collaboratively-not only the states and the Commonwealth but also business and union representatives-to make sure that we had a group of people whose task was to address the training needs of this country. Well, this government has just decided to abolish it. The government clearly are not serious about boosting the role of vocational education and training; otherwise we would see a much more substantial investment in this bill. They have MAIN COMMITTEE not offered the states any extra growth funding, which is why they have not been able to secure an agreement with the states for the next round of ANTA funding. The government have just walked away-taken their bat and ball-and have decided to abolish ANTA, along with being unable to negotiate a new agreement. For eight long years the Howard government has been wasting talent and missing economic opportunities because it refuses to act to address this growing skills crisis. This did not just happen yesterday and it did not just happen since the election; it has been happening over the last eight years. And the government has not only done nothing about it; if you go back to the early days of this government, its first few budgets had a disastrous impact on the funding for vocational education and training. Our workplaces are facing skills shortages, there is a serious shortage of TAFE places, wage pressures are jeopardising local industry and, of course, families are suffering as wellsuffering because they have to pay more to get their homes built. They will certainly have to pay more if they want a brick home because there is now a new levy on the price of bricks. I hope everybody who is thinking about either doing an extension or building a new home recognises that the increase in the cost of extending or building their brick home is a direct result of the Howard government not properly funding the number of bricklayers in training, and so the industry has been forced to put on this additional levy. The government have had a long time to get this right. They have had eight years to invest in world-class training, but they have not done that; they have just ignored this area. I am sorry to say that this bill is yet another wasted opportunity-yet another wasted and missed opportunity-because it does not provide the additional funding and the additional places for training that our country needs. You do not have to take my word for it; just look at what the Australian Industry Group says about the shortage of workers. This bill today will do nothing to address the shortages that the Australian Industry Group has identified. This bill just extends funding to the training sector for next year. The big disappointment is that it has no additional growth. Here we have a government putting forward a bill in the face of a very serious skills crisis, with no additional growth funding-none-to help cut down the queues of people waiting to get into TAFE and no long-term solution to the training crisis gripping Australian business. I for one know that none of us in this parliament can afford complacency in this vocational education and training area. So, after eight years of neglect, the government are trying to reinvent themselves as a party interested in skills and apprenticeships. When they first came in, they slashed the budget. Then they froze the funding for a few years. They have realised they created this severe skills crisis and know they have to do something-but this bill is not part of it. This bill is certainly not doing anything to add to the training opportunities for Australians, because there is no growth funding associated with it. Instead of building on the successful elements of the existing system, next year the government is intending to create these new technical colleges. As some members of the coalition themselves have said, this will create unnecessary duplication. The abolition of ANTA also clearly signals the end of tripartite collaborative negotiations in this area. No longer will we have a place where all the parties can come together and work out what is best for training in this country. This is particularly important if we are to protect the national training system and to make sure that, for business and for employees, we have qualifications and courses that are recognised right across Australia. The last thing we want is MAIN COMMITTEE a return to a system where qualifications are recognised only in individual states or very narrowly accredited. That would be a disaster for both employers and workers. The highest priority should be given to delivering adequate funding to make sure that our local TAFEs have the money that they need and make sure that there are work and training opportunities for those 45,000 young people who every year-I wonder when the government will wake up to this issue-leave school early. Every year for eight years we have had 45,000 young people leave school early. They join the unemployment queue. They are not going into training, they are not staying at school and they are the people who we should be targeting to make sure that we can get them into training and that they do not face a life of long-term unemployment. It was Labor that actually introduced the first vocational education and training funding bill. We also set up the Australian National Training Authority so that apprentices could have a well-funded national education system. It was an unprecedented commitment to the training of young Australians in particular. We spent our time trying to build up a great training system. Unfortunately, over the last eight years we have seen a government running it down. As I said, this run-down of training has become a major concern of industry. The Australian Industry Group have released report after report, trying to get the Howard government to focus on the growing skills crisis. I quote from one of their reports: Over half of the businesses surveyed currently face skill shortages. Regional businesses in NSW (60% currently face skill shortages) are most acutely impacted followed by businesses in regional Victoria (48%) and Queensland (41%). According to the Australian Industry Group, skill shortages in Australia are endemic‘endemic’ is the word the AIG uses. There is a shortage of around 20,000 workers. This government is not providing growth funding in this bill. The AIG’s warning is that the skills crisis facing Australian industry is here and now. The AIG must be very frustrated that it has a government that is not listening. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry is also seriously concerned. This is what a survey of investor confidence, published this year, had to say: For only the second time in the history of the survey Business Taxes and Charges ... has been removed from its position as the foremost constraint on investment. Taking number one position for the first time is the Availability of Suitably Qualified Employees ... A much tighter labour market for skilled workers has seen this constraint rise from fifth highest just a year ago to second position in January and April, then finally to first in the current quarter. The first issue for business, the biggest concern for ACCI members, was the growing shortage of skills. The Senate Employment, Workplace Relations and Education References Committee has also found that Australia does not have enough skilled metal engineering and manufacturing workers to carry out the $20 billion worth of major infrastructure and resource projects expected in the next 10 years. Industry groups and a Senate committee have recognised a serious risk to economic performance and productivity resulting from this government’s lack of action over the last eight years. Unlike this government, we took a policy to the last election to boost Australian skill levels and address shortages in a much more substantial way. Our strategy to build the skill levels of the Australian work force included the following: an additional 36,600 real growth placesthat is over and above the money being provided in this bill-including 20,000 new TAFE places, and a commitment, which I think was very important, to pay the TAFE fees of seconMAIN COMMITTEE dary school students. There was not a limit on the number of young people who could go to technical colleges. We were saying that all secondary school students who wanted to gain vocational qualifications while they were still at school would have their TAFE fees paid by a federal Labor government. Our strategy also included 6,600 skill-up apprenticeships through group training in regions of high unemployment or skill shortage; a significant increase in funding for group training organisations to support small and medium enterprises and to create up to 8,000 additional apprenticeships; more opportunities for mature age Australians to update their skills; a training bonus for aged care and child-care trainees who complete their training; and national protocols to make sure that TAFE fees and charges are affordable. The government complain about these TAFE fees, but they do not do anything about it. I do not know what they think they are in government for. They are not there to have a whinge; they are actually there to fix problems. Our policy also included a quality training agreement with state and territory governments to address current and emerging skill shortages and to make sure all apprentices and trainees receive quality training. These initiatives built on Labor’s commitment to create 20,000 additional university places every year, including in nursing, teacher education and medicine. It also augmented a terrific program we wanted to put in place, called Bright Futures. This was a school based program to help schools raise the awareness of post secondary work and study options, including the benefits of a career in traditional trades. These initiatives form a comprehensive strategy to tackle the skills crisis and boost Australia’s skills level. Compare that to what we are debating here today: a bill that has no growth at all to address this serious skills shortage that we face right now-a shortage that has been described as endemic by the Australian Industry Group, a shortage that is not in any way, most unfortunately, addressed by the bill. Of course we want to see this money flow, but I say to the government: you need much more than this if we are going to address the very serious skills crisis that this government faces. of the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 and bring to the attention of members the important role of vocational education and training in assisting young people to reach their full potential and to find their own place in the world of work. This government has actually made significant progress, despite the words we have just heard, in developing vocational education pathways for the 70 per cent of young people who do not go directly from school to university. Currently, 95 per cent of secondary schools across Australia offer vocational education and training programs. Certainly in my electorate of Bass in Northern Tasmania there is a level of involvement to varying degrees in every secondary school and college. I take this opportunity today to congratulate the teachers and principals in these schools who have had the foresight and the professionalism to introduce these programs into the curriculum. I especially commend them where they have used VET courses as a way of re-engaging difficult or at-risk students who stand to genuinely benefit from this extra option while at school. There has been significant growth in the numbers undertaking VET in schools from around 60,000 in 1996 when the Howard government came to office to almost 203,000 today. That is rather a different picture to the one just painted for us by the Deputy Leader of the OpposiMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Michael Ferguson (Bass) (4.55 P.m.)
theText: TodayI wish to speak in strong supporttion. Nationally that represents 44 per cent of all senior secondary students. There has also been a large increase in the number of young people undertaking school based new apprenticeships. There are now 14,000 young people in school based apprenticeships compared to just 1,500 in 1998. This is nearly a tenfold increase. Will we as politicians ever be really able to understand the good this has done for our families and our young people? I am confident that for every student who takes up this option with the support of their family and their school there is a success story of a satisfied, fulfilled young person very happy to be doing something worthwhile and looking forward to a real career with a real job. These pathways provide young people with industry recognised qualifications and provide viable pathways for those young people who do not wish to go to university for whatever reasons they may have for not wanting a tertiary education. However, too often the message is sent to young Australians that a career in a trade is not as valued and not as valuable as a university qualification. This message has contributed to the growing skill shortage we are facing today and to the high drop-out rate of students in their first year of university. Australia’s university drop-out rate is among the highest in the developed world: 40 per cent of students who begin university study do not complete it. Government analysis shows that 100,000 of the 228,000 people who got a HECS place at university this year will not finish that course and 40,000 will have left before the end of the year and will never come back. How can this be happening? It is because so many of them are striving for university entry but have no particular long-term purpose in doing so except to gain a tertiary award. Perhaps they do not really know what they want to do with their lives; perhaps some have virtually had the decision made for them by their family, by their college or school or by their peers. But, for whatever reason it is happening, it stands to say that so many people are missing the opportunity to reach their potential and to attain personal fulfilment in their lives. WhatI will not dwell on today but would like to mention is that for those students who do drop out of university there is an enormous price to be paid: the accumulation of a HECS debt without reaching the goal that it contributes towards paying for; the social cost and embarrassment; and, more importantly, the months or years that are in many cases simply lost to that individual. Another price that we as a community pay is having a large number of young people who have been taught to feel that there is no prestige if they only want to leave school and get a trade, as if it were an inferior option to tertiary study. As a former schoolteacher of maths, science and IT at Kings Meadows High School, I impressed upon as many of my students as I could our school motto, ‘We have our part to play.’ We have all heard how the abolition of technical colleges by the states has meant that over the past few decades many young people have lacked clear training and skills pathways, particularly the 70 per cent of those who choose to not go directly from school to university. Unlike the previous speaker, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I am excited about the Howard government’s pledge to invest $289 million over four years to establish 24 Australian technical colleges. These will promote pride and excellence in the teaching and acquiring of skills at the secondary school level. These colleges, one of which is to be based in my own region of Northern Tasmania, will be open to talented year 11 and 12 students interested in gaining a trade, but while also being able to complete their secondary schooling. I am saddened, however, by Labor’s negative, rhetorical approach to this important initiative. Repeatedly in the House of Representatives question time since the opening of the parliament, quesMAIN COMMITTEE tions from members of the Labor Party on the subject of Australian technical colleges have uniformly described them as ‘overdue and insufficient’. We have just heard the Deputy Leader of the Opposition say also that the Australian technical colleges will make barely a dent in the skills shortages in Australia. What a sad comment. The fact is that these select high-achievement colleges will provide tuition for up to 7,200 young people in years 11 and 12 every year. They will be implemented from 2006, within virtually one year from now-not the mystical four-year figure which is being used. Students at the colleges will be able to undertake academic, information technology and business courses. They will graduate from the colleges with trade, entrepreneurial and business skills, with the capacity to be self-employed in the future or to go on to further education and training. All students would have the opportunity to take up a school based new apprenticeship. Colleges will be endorsed and led by industry. They will be run autonomously by principals, who will be able to engage teaching staff on a performance pay basis. Interestingly, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition referred fairly frequently to the Australian Industry Group. In a press release on 24 November, Ms Macklin stated that the government’s Australian technical colleges were not a solution to skills shortages and that the government should address this issue immediately. However, this was not a view shared by industry. On the same day, a press release issued by the Australian Industry Group expressed strong support for the initiative and applauded the government’s leadership in addressing the skills shortages issue. To me, these words from members of the Labor Party are a disgrace. If they secretly thought that the colleges were a good idea, good public policy and good for addressing the issues that we are all concerned about, then they could at least have kept quiet about it and let the bill go through. They could even have publicly supported it, reversing their predictable opposition from the time the policy was launched during the election campaign. But these new Australian technical colleges need to be supported, they need to be championed, and Labor ought to spell out right now what they would do when the Australian technical colleges are progressively opened from 2005. Will they support them then? They need also to say what they would do to them if they won office after the next election. Would they mothball them? Would they still describe them as insufficient? Or was it a Freudian slip for them to describe them as ‘overdue’ and they do actually believe that they may have some merit? Also, during question time today I heard the answers to the questions asked by the Labor members that I have referred to. I listened to Minister Hardgrave’s answers when on each occasion Labor members were interjecting with calls such as, ‘You have had eight years to fix this,’ or, ‘You have done nothing for eight years,’ and other claims that somehow the government had been asleep at the wheel. This is breathtaking hypocrisy. Are the Labor members claiming that the government has missed its opportunity to address a skills shortage that existed in 1996 after they had left office after 13 years in government? No, I do not think they are saying that. The fact is that Australia is, in a way, a victim of its own success. Strong economic management, responsible decisions, not being beholden to unions, effective employment programs, industrial relations reforms and welfare reforms have rescued Australia. Today we have a strong and growing economy, consistent budget surpluses, lower income tax rates, MAIN COMMITTEE evaporating government debt from the $96 billion debt left to us by Labor, more people in work, higher participation and an unemployment rate that is virtually half what it once was. The growing economy has caused the higher demand for skills. The demand for skills has employed more people, which means that the pool of people left to take up new skills and provide them has been reduced. In short, under Labor we had people looking for jobs; under the Howard government we have jobs looking for people. This is, with due respect to the seriousness of the challenge, a good problem to have. Also during the previous speech we heard of unmet demand in Australia. In fact, as the previous speaker correctly identified, today we have unmet demand in TAFE colleges in Australia at around the 40,000 level. I think it is important for me to remind members that, on the government’s coming to office, that figure was 89,000, so there has been quite a dramatic turnaround since that time. It also has to be said that the government, with the leadership shown in the past and even today from the Minister for Education, Science and Training, have turned a spotlight on the issues and we are actively doing something about them. In contrast, Labor have sat on their hands. The Minister for Education, Science and Training reported on Labor’s sudden interest as recently as August this year, prior to the recent election. He said in the chamber on 11 August: In the almost three years I have had the privilege to be this country’s Minister for Education, Science and Training, I have had 59 questions in question time. Fifty-four of those questions have been about universities, and five have been about training-and in those five questions the word ‘apprenticeship’ appeared once, as an afterthought. In relation to funding for TAFE colleges through the ANTA agreement, I say this: if Labor were serious about TAFE, then during the failed ANTA agreement negotiations earlier this year and even prior to that, when the federal government offered ongoing increases of 2½ per cent on the condition that states would increase their own funding to their own colleges by just 1½ per cent, they should have picked up the phone and told their Labor colleagues in the various states and territories to sign on the dotted line. This government has also taken steps to strengthen careers advice. Earlier this year the Minister for Education, Science and Training announced two initiatives to address this issue. One was a professional development package for careers advisers, including a best practice resource for all careers teachers in secondary schools, an accredited online course to enhance the skills of career and transition advisers, and an elective course in career education to be offered as part of Bachelor of Education degrees. Another initiative was the Career Education Lighthouse Schools Project, which aims to support the leaders in career education programs in schools and promote best practice models to other schools. These measures will assist students to navigate their way through their career options, make the most of their vocational learning experiences and make a smooth transition from school to work. Raising the profile of the benefits of VET in Schools pathways is also of major importance. The challenge is to ensure that both students and their parents recognise the value of VET qualifications and the pathways they can offer. To acknowledge the achievements of those students who have chosen VET in Schools pathways, a national student prize for VET in Schools students and school based New Apprenticeships students, consisting of a cash prize of $2,000, will be awarded to 450 VET in Schools students and 50 school based New Apprenticeships students each year across Australia. This initiative will support students MAIN COMMITTEE in exploring a variety of options when they are making crucial choices about their futures. The national student prize will also encourage parents to talk to their children about the importance of VET in Schools programs and the career opportunities that are available to them in a broad range of industries. This bill will provide further funding for the development of strategic initiatives to expand the range of VET in Schools programs and enhance transitions to employment and further education for students. In reply to the previous speaker I only have one further comment, and that is in relation to the description of this bill as somehow being a reduction in money to the states and territories. This plainly ignores or disregards the fact that during the breakdown in negotiations toward the next ANTA agreement, where the states declined the offer of increased funding because presumably they did not wish to dip into their own coffers, the government’s response was to take the additional money which was being pledged and to simply tender it out to the local community. That tender process created 7,500 places around the country. In conclusion, the Howard government’s commitment to vocational education and training is strong. It is illustrated by the significant funding provided through this bill and the new initiatives announced this year, particularly in addressing skills shortages. Since 1996 the coalition government has reinvigorated vocational education and training with record numbers in training, record numbers in new apprenticeships and significant progress toward developing a high-quality, truly national system. Today, 12 per cent of Australia’s working age population is in VET training. This year the Australian government will spend a record $2.1 billion on vocational education and training, which will underpin this nation’s strong economic growth and low unemployment. We have also announced new measures in our election commitments to a total of $1.06 billion over four years. This is one of the most significant boosts to vocational education and training ever undertaken by any government. This bill will provide the Australian government funding required to support Australia’s world-class vocational education and training system in 2005, and I commend it to the House. Dr EMERSON (Rankin) (5.12 p.m.)-Government contributors to this debate on the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 have been saying at the same time that the skills shortage confronting Australia is a great problem to have and that they have taken all of these measures to avert a skills shortage in Australia. The truth is that the government cannot have it both ways. The fact of the matter is that there is an acute skills shortage in this country and it is not a great problem to have. It is a serious problem for our economic prospects both in the short term and, just as importantly, in the longer term. I want to outline the dimensions of the skills shortage in Australia. The Australian Industry Group has found that in the manufacturing sector there are between 18,000 and 21,000 unfilled vacancies for tradespeople. I do not think that is a great problem to have. Further, the Australian Industry Group has identified that numbers of traditional apprenticeships have remained pretty much unchanged since 1996, when the Howard government took office. So when this government talks about apprenticeships it does not talk about traditional apprenticeships as the people of Australia know them but of some variation or cheap inversion of apprenticeships. Traditional apprenticeships have not grown under the Howard government. Indeed, according to the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations skilled vacancy index, vacanMAIN COMMITTEE cies for skilled tradespeople have increased by an astonishing 54 per cent over the last three years. According to the Australian Industry Group, right now Australia has a shortage of around 20,000 skilled workers in sectors like carpentry, construction, manufacturing and mining. The Australian Industry Group says that over the next five years 175,000 people are expected to leave the traditional trades but only 70,000 will enter. That means a skills shortage in the traditional trades of more than 100,000 workers. That is not a great problem to have. Instead of wasting millions of dollars duplicating the Australian TAFE system and limiting new training to just a few, the Howard government should fund our TAFEs properly and invest in more genuine apprenticeships in areas of skills shortage. The government refused to fund any new TAFE places between 1997 and 2001. The same government provided only one-third of the funding states and territories needed between 2001 and 2003. This bill will reduce the level of funds for vocational education that are provided to the Australian National Training Authority for distribution to the states and territories in 2004. The funding will fall from $1.36 billion to $1.31 billion. What is the government’s response to the skill shortage? It is to cut funding to the Australian National Training Authority in 2004. Indeed, looking at the history of this government, in its first two budgets it slashed $240 million out of vocational education and training. Then it followed up with the 1998-2000 ANTA agreement that abolished growth funding altogether and froze funding to the sector for at least three years. Here is a looming skills shortage, which started emerging in the mid-1990s. The first response of the Howard government to that skills shortage was to take $240 million out of vocational education and training and then follow it up by freezing funding, no growth funding, in the subsequent years. Those funding cuts and a subsequent freeze meant more and more of the TAFE colleges closed their training facilities, putting teachers and students under a lot of pressure. To cap it all off, the government has announced that it will close down the Australian National Training Authority. That was a vehicle to work collaboratively with the states, and the Howard government has obviously made a judgment that it does not want to work collaboratively with the states in addressing the acute skill shortages that have built up while the government has taken action to cut funding for vocational education and training and then to freeze it. I foreshadowed this sort of response in the great GST debate when we talked about the Prime Minister’s great tax adventure and the Treasurer’s streamlined new tax system for a new century. It was clear that the government was going to allow specific purpose payments to the states to erode over time. On the day that the GST was introduced, the government abolished $18 billion in untied grants. It was plain to see that the government would allow the tied grants-which were of a similar order of magnitude-used for such purposes as vocational education and training to erode, contravening the spirit of the memorandum of understanding that was signed by the Treasurer, Prime Minister and state premiers. I remember well the Treasurer saying, ‘We have this memorandum of understanding and it will guarantee no cuts to the specific purpose payments.’ The way to reduce the value of specific purpose payments is not to adjust them for cost increases and general inflation and allow them to erode with population growth instead of providing the same per capita amount. Those two mechanisms were available to the government. Like a big, black, hungry dog, the government got in there and made sure that those two mechanisms were used effectively to erode the specific purpose payments to the states. Here, MAIN COMMITTEE today, we have evidence of that, and only a few years after the government said: ‘Trust us. We have signed a memorandum of understanding with the states. We won’t do it.’ Well, they did. We knew they would. We knew they would do it in health. We knew they would do it in education. And this bill today shows that is exactly what they have done. Government members are saying that a skill shortage is a great problem to have. I need to relay the story of Australian productivity growth, because today’s productivity growth is tomorrow’s prosperity. Labor recognised that when it was last in government and set out a major, comprehensive economic reform program designed to lift productivity growth in this country. Labor knew that the yield from those reforms would take some time, and, indeed it did. But Labor was patient, Labor was determined and Labor had a coherent program of economic reforms designed to lift productivity growth. When those reforms were implemented, by the early 1990s productivity growth in Australia did indeed begin to respond. From 1993 right through to the current day, Australian productivity growth has been faster than almost every country in the world-faster than most countries in the world, with the exception of Finland and Ireland. So those economic reforms did work. Labor created the open, competitive economy. Labor opened the door to competition, both from abroad and from here in Australia, and it lifted productivity growth. When you see the Treasurer crowing about strong economic growth in this country, he is in fact crowing about the returns, the dividends, the yield from that economic reform program instituted by the Hawke and Keating governments. However, having opened the door once to create the open, competitive economy, you cannot open the same door twice. You can keep it open and you can push it a little bit further where possible. That is why the Productivity Commission recently released a report advocating further reforms in competition policy and an improvement in the efficiency of various industries and infrastructure provision in this country. But the Productivity Commission knows that the main game-the opening of the economy-has already occurred. We now come to the point in 2002 when the Intergenerational Report was released. The Intergenerational Report contains very worrying forecasts. The Intergenerational Report forecasts that Australian productivity growth from next year, 2005, will slip back to our 30year mediocre long-term average-that is, down from 2.05 per cent during the late 1990s to 1.75 per cent for the coming decades. That 1.75 per cent productivity growth is a serious problem for Australia because we are confronted with the ageing of the population and it will be productivity growth almost exclusively that Australia will need to use to combat the ageing of the population. The ageing of the population is a fact. The die is cast. To invoke the phrase used by the Treasurer: ‘demography is destiny’. The ageing of the population is a result of decisions made by parents over the last 40 years that will affect the age profile of the Australian population over the next 40 years. So the die is cast. We cannot prevent the ageing of the population. Fertility continues to decline and it is forecast to decline further to 1.65 per cent over the 40-year projection period. That forecast is contained in the Intergenerational Report. So, if the die is cast on the ageing of the population, we need to rely on strong productivity growth to combat the effects of the ageing population on Australian prosperity. We may ask: what are the forecasts for per capita GDP growth, which is the best available measure of the growth in living standards in Australia? The forecasts contained in the Intergenerational ReMAIN COMMITTEE port are for a slump in Australia’s per capita GDP growth from 2010 onwards that would constitute the slowest rate of growth in that measure of living standards since the decade of the Great Depression. Everyone in this room and this parliament should be alarmed at those forecasts and should be doing everything possible to prevent those forecasts from becoming a reality-and we can. If we were able to maintain the productivity growth of the late 1990s that has been going on through to the early 2000s then we could successfully deal with the ageing of the population. Yet it requires us to identify the new sources of productivity growth because, if we have opened the door to competition, if we have created an open, competitive economy and we cannot open that door a second time, we must identify the new sources of productivity growth. The international evidence on this matter is stark. It is clear: the strongest, most powerful, most potent source of productivity growth in the Western world is skills formation. That brings us back to this legislation, because at a time when we should be investing in skills the Howard government is disinvesting. It is running down our skills base. It is divesting in skills in this country at exactly the wrong time. time. These are not just statements from a Labor Party politician; they are statements from people who have analysed these matters. I will cite some of those. The OECD, in a major international study in 2003, identified skills generation, skills formation, as the most important source of productivity growth in the 20th century, followed by investment in innovation and, thirdly, by investment in infrastructure and, of course, keeping the economy open and trading with other countries. So what is the Australian experience with skills formation, of which this legislation is a reflection? It is a very sorry experience indeed. I will quote from the Productivity Commission. This is a damning indictment on the Howard government, because the Productivity Commission said: ... the weight of evidence suggests there was a slower rate of accumulation of human capital in the Australian workforce in the 1990s, which all else equal would have detracted from a productivity acceleration in the 1990s. In other words, that strong productivity growth that was achieved out of the economic reform programs of the Hawke and Keating years was weakened by a detraction caused by a slowdown in skills formation. Similarly, the Productivity Commission said: ... there appears to have been no significant acceleration in workforce skills in the 1990s. In fact, the evidence shows a faster increase in skills in the 1980swhen Labor was in power. These conclusions are confirmed by the OECD’s empirical work, which indicates that skill upgrading made no contribution to Australian productivity growth between 1990 and 2000. Drawing together the work of the OECD and the Productivity Commission, Saul Eslake asked this question: ... why has education apparently not made any discernible contribution to the improvement in Australia’s economic performance over the past decade? The answer, unfortunately, seems to be that there has MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Danby
theText: We haven’t even got enough bricklayers.
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Dr Emerson
theText: Not enough bricklayers, not enough tradespeople, at exactly the wrongnot been any discernible improvement in Australia’s educational outcomes-at least insofar as they impact on productivity growth-during this period. Saul Eslake is the Chief Economist for the ANZ Bank. He is no lackey of the Australian Labor Party and that is the conclusion that he has drawn. Steve Dowrick at the ANU has had a very extensive career in looking at skills formation as a source of productivity growth in Australia and overseas-a lot of empirical work-and his conclusion is this: These international comparisons suggest that Australia’s educational report card should be marked: ‘Started well, but slackened off. Substantial room for improvement.’ What an indictment on the Howard government. What an indictment that we have legislation here today that involves the abolition of the Australian National Training Authority and the continuation of completely inadequate funding for skills in this country. Skills formation is a big problem now and investing in skills is the best investment that we can imagine in this country, and yet we have a piece of legislation that abolishes the Australian National Training Authority and pursues the Howard government’s ideological agenda of bypassing the states. The government has announced that it will set up its own technical colleges that will not be completed for another four years. So this is the government’s urgent response to the urgent problem of skills shortages in this country: to announce an initiative in the election that will produce no discernible improvement in skills in this country for another four years, and yet the government has the temerity to say that this is a great problem to have-it is boasting that this is the problem that it has. Well, it is not a problem for the Howard government; it is a problem for Australia. Unless we turn around this government’s attitude towards skills formation in Australia the Productivity Commission’s work, the Intergenerational Report forecasts, will all come true-that is, from the end of this decade, in this country, we will have the slowest rate of growth per person since the decade of the Great Depression. You would think it probably could not get much worse than that, but it does, because the forecasts for the subsequent decade, the 2020s, are for an even slower rate of growth. If we are to combat the ageing of the population, we must invest in skills in this country now. This legislation fails to do that. It abolishes the Australian National Training Authority, it pursues the government’s ideological agenda-the government is not interested in cooperating with the states-and it realises the government’s intentions back in the year 2000, when it signed a sham memorandum of understanding with the states, saying that it would maintain specific purpose payments to the states in all areas. It has done nothing of the sort, and it has betrayed the future of this country and of all young people who live in this country, young people who yearn for a decent opportunity in life and for the skills to enable them to develop their talents and contribute to this great country. This is one of the most shameful pieces of legislation that have ever been brought into this parliament. It is one of the first pieces of legislation brought into the parliament in the new term of the Howard government. It shows how miserable and mean it is when it comes to investing in the nation’s future, when it comes to investing in the talents of our young people, and the government should be condemned for it. Amendment Bill 2004 is another progressive piece of legislation from the Howard government. It is interesting to listen to our opponents, who explain that the sun will not rise tomorMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Wakelin (Grey) (5.31 P.m.)
theText: The Vocational Education and Training Fundingrow because of the terrible way the government are running the country. The opposition cannot escape the fact that apprenticeship numbers in this country have nearly tripled in the time that we have been in control of the Treasury benches. I think it is really important to note the whole change in culture that our government have been working towards over many years. When you add a progressive policy approach and the desire to establish 24 Australian technical colleges, as well as the belief that skills other than those attained in the universities of this country are of equal value to them, then you get an idea of the direction of this government and its commitment to the working people of this country. It is a particular pleasure for me to rise to contribute to this debate today. As someone who has not had the opportunity to participate in an apprenticeship scheme, university or even years 11 and 12, and as someone who comes from rural and regional Australia, there is nothing more important to my mind than seeing this sort of legislation in the parliament and people having the opportunity to remind anyone who cares to listen, but particularly the young people of Australia, that what they do with their young lives in terms of developing skills is of equal value to what others do, whether they be doctors of medicine, doctors of philosophy, schoolteachers, nurses or whatever. It is so important that we get in this country an equal opportunity for every Australian, and this is what this legislation is about. I will say a few words about the 24 Australian technical colleges, the Australian network of industry career advisers and of course the financial assistance for Commonwealth trade learning scholarships, toolkits and residential support for new apprenticeships. Coming from an electorate that is 1,000 kilometres by 1,000 kilometres-just under one million square kilometres-I can say that residential support for new apprenticeships is a very significant step forward, with the youth allowance being offered in a way that is only being offered to a particular sector of the community. I also remind the Main Committee that not only have we seen almost a trebling in the number of apprentices in this country over the last eight or nine years but we have seen a very significant reduction in unemployment. And now this whole debate about the shortage of skills right across industry and right across the economy demonstrates clearly the strength of our economy. This is a government that not only supports every Australian and encourages every Australian but puts into place policies within an economy strong enough to deliver on those aspirations which are so vital to every Australian, particularly every young Australian. While I am thinking about young Australians it is very timely, particularly with the issues on Palm Island, for me to talk about young Aboriginal Australians. As the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs in the 41st Parliament, can I say that there is no more important issue than offering young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people the opportunity to be employed. This sort of legislation, in cooperation with the states and territories-they are vital-is absolutely essential to the future of Aboriginal people. Unless we can offer the hope, the self-esteem and the opportunity for young Aboriginal people to develop the skills to work in their communities and to have a productive life, we will only continue the tragedies that Palm Island has witnessed over these last few days. I am always delighted to speak on this sort of legislation, this sort of acknowledgment of the value of every Australian, particularly those Australians who are not necessarily academically inclined. The opportunities for regional, rural and remote young people in particular, in MAIN COMMITTEE the tertiary sector, in the university sector and even in the TAFE sector, are very limited when we look at the opportunities in our urban centres. This bill, supported by the policy announcements from the last election, has given us the hope of and supported the aspiration of young people to a very positive future. There is more to be done, because if you live 1,000 kilometres away from a centre of learning, whether it is a TAFE, a university or any other institution which enhances education, then you are behind the eight ball. And then, if you have financial circumstances that, compared to those of most other Australians, add a bill of $5,000 or $10,000 per annum in order to have that opportunity, it is something which I have to describe as still being work in progress. With great pleasure I support the bill and wish it every success. The measure of this bill will be particularly in the years ahead, as we see the vision that this government has given and will continue to give this country through its leadership, offering young people great opportunities to develop their skills. Ms GEORGE (Throsby) (5.38 p.m.)-I rise to speak on the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 because it provides another opportunity for me as the member for Throsby to put on the public record my congratulations regarding the wonderful efforts of the staff and the directors of the Illawarra Institute of TAFE for our region. While located in Wollongong, of course, the institute has campuses in many outlying areas. The vocational education and TAFE system is a remarkable system, publicly funded and publicly accessible, that provides a wide range of educational opportunities. I visit the TAFE colleges quite regularly and talk to the teachers about some of the issues that they face as workers in the system. I also appreciate the very important role that the TAFE system plays in advancing the economic issues and dealing with the imperatives that face our regional economy. It is a wonderful system because it provides opportunities for the young and not-soyoung, giving a lot of adults in particular a second chance and a second go. Its courses range from traditional trade training through to basic literacy and numeracy. In our area, particularly important are the programs for newly arrived immigrants and refugees in basic English language. It is also a system that is critical for Australia’s future economic success. In that regard I have to express my profound disappointment that the bill before us in fact reduces and limits the funding that is available this year to that very important system. It is amazing that, at a time when we all acknowledge the importance of productivity and economic growth-and investment in human capital is going to be a really important marker for the next spurt of productivity improvements that will sustain our competitiveness-we find this government actually reducing the level of funds available for this system. As the brief indicates, the funding will fall from $1.36 billion to $1.31 billion, largely as a result of the incapacity of the federal government to reach agreement with the states in the last round of ANTA negotiations. When you look back at the record of the Howard government it is quite an appalling record for this important sector of our education and training system. The first two budgets, of course, saw cuts to the system, followed by a freeze in funds at a time when growth in demand was outstripping available places. For years the TAFE directors unanimously have been arguing the case that the government has a responsibility to provide extra funding to meet the unmet demand if we are going to meet the challenges that we all know are important for our nation. The government walked away from trying to finalise an MAIN COMMITTEE agreement. I was not surprised when the states maintained a firm position of rejection of the offer that was made by the federal government through the minister. The government has really failed the challenge of seeing the critical role of this sector and funding it in a way that provides continuing opportunities for all Australians, particularly young people, those who want to continue the route of trade training and those who see TAFE as a system for providing upskilling of workers already at work. All of this is going to impact severely-and is impacting severely-on Australian businesses; and not just on businesses but also on the students, many of whom are rejected year after year even though they have the capacity to successfully undertake courses. With that freeze in funding and the limit on growth funding, enormous pressure has been placed on the extremely dedicated staff who I know work at the local institutions and those who I daresay work in other areas. I think we all understand the imperatives that warrant a much better resourced system than is there at the moment. I guess that, when you just look at the statistics, you do not see things as clearly as you do when you are actually dealing with the outcomes of a system that is inadequately funded and resourced. I want to talk a little bit about the impact that the government’s complacent attitude is having on the regional economy of the Illawarra and the huge crisis we are facing, with youth unemployment levels hovering around 30 per cent at a time when we have a crisis in terms of skill shortages in the area. I would have thought that, if anything, the fact that business is screaming about the problems in attracting skilled labour would have been sounding alarm bells for this government, but it seems not to be the case. We have had at best a very pathetic response. The only tangible response has been the proposal to create 24 additional TAFE colleges, which will not be up and running for a few years at a time when industry is crying out for skilled labour now. What a waste of taxpayer funds, to put that money into creating an alternative system-alternative structures, alternative bureaucracies, alternative collegeswhen that money could be so easily and readily absorbed by the existing TAFE institutions! There is no rationale or justification for expending taxpayer funds in establishing a duplicate TAFE college system. Regrettably, the Howard government has not heeded the warnings that have been given for some time now by industry, by the union movement, by the TAFE system and by the TAFE directors. There was a recent Senate inquiry which obviously the government has taken no notice of. One wonders why enormous amounts of time, energy and resources are put into producing well-researched documents with comprehensive recommendations when they only sit on a shelf and are ignored. The report of that Senate inquiry, entitled Bridging the skills divide, outlined the seriousness of the situation facing Australia. I think we would be very foolish if we did not recognise that the current and projected skill shortages are going to threaten Australia’s future economic capacity and development. You do not have to take my word for that. The Australian Industry Group made it very clear in its submission to the Senate inquiry that over half of the businesses it surveyed face skill shortages. And ACCI, one of the other peak organisations, said to the inquiry that ‘Australian firms are greatly concerned at their incapacity to recruit employees with appropriate levels of skills and retain skilled employees, with such pressures being particularly acute in regional and rural Australia’. Recent research conducted by the ACTU estimates that the growing shortage of skilled workers, particularly in the traditional trades, will cost the Australian economy up to $9 bilMAIN COMMITTEE lion in lost output over the next decade. That body of research also estimated that, on current intakes and projections, over the next five years up to 170,000 tradespeople will leave industry and only 40,000 will be entering. With an ageing population-and we hear a lot about the ageing of the population, but it applies equally to the traditional trades areas-we are not training enough young people to replace the looming shortages that are going to emerge in those traditional areas. Again, if you do not believe me, have a look at the government’s own figures, which show that the job vacancies in the traditional trades are now at their highest level for 15 years. In fact, the recent departmental skilled vacancies index, which looks at the vacancies for skilled tradespeople, showed a 54 per cent jump in vacancies, rising from 97.1 per cent in November 2001 to 149.4 per cent in November 2004. This has all been happening while the Howard government has been in power-when it has been asleep on its watch. This skills shortage that everyone had been referring to for years continues unabated with no constructive solutions to redress the critical situation. As I said earlier, the government’s belated-and, at best, only half-hearted-publicly indefensible policy response was its proposal to establish 24 new colleges. From what I understand, they will not start operating until 2006 and will not be fully operational for some years after that. Even then, these new colleges will provide training to fewer than two per cent of year 11 and 12 students. An estimated 7½ thousand students in years 11 and 12 might get the option of undertaking a course at the colleges. You have to ask the question: is that the best means of expending taxpayers’ funds to address a crisis that exists now? It is not a crisis that will be there in four years time; it is a crisis that is there now. While attracting young people into trade training and apprenticeships is important, it is really a drop in the ocean in terms of the magnitude of the problem. As I said, it does nothing to help the crisis now. The Australian Industry Group, the AiG, in their document looking at regional indicators which was released recently, said that the crisis is ‘endemic’, with an estimated 20,000 job vacancies in manufacturing alone. I would argue that the money set aside for the creation of these new colleges should be redirected immediately to create and open up new TAFE places, to do what we are attempting to do in the Illawarra in our apprenticeship pilot, which extends into the member for Gilmore’s area too. We have been able, with small incentives, to create in the space of eight months 60 additional apprenticeship opportunities for young people who would have missed out otherwise. The government should assist local organisations who are grappling with their own regional solutions to the particular nature of the skills crisis that confronts them. The government needs to move away from the top-down approach and have faith in communities to come up with solutions that best fit their particular needs. In my view, what would best meet the needs of employers, students and families in our area would be to redirect that money immediately into a well-functioning system that has provided lots of opportunities in the past and can do even better with additional resources and funding. I think the government has also failed to develop a strategy for, and have a clear understanding of, the impact of skills shortages at a regional level. It is fair to say that you can access data on national and state trends, and the department does that adequately, but when you try and go beyond those global statistics to look at the impact at a regional level it is sadly wanting. The government needs to develop a clearer picture of the impact of the skills shortages at a regional level in order to assist businesses in trying to develop a coordinated solution MAIN COMMITTEE to address the problem. There is no magic bullet and there is not one solution that in itself is going to solve the crisis. What we have done in the Illawarra is to rely on limited data that has been collected by a range of organisations. I mention that AiG Illawarra did a survey based on 44 local companies. Of those 44 companies-a limited survey-91 per cent said they were experiencing skills shortages. Based on that, current and projected skills needs were 740 positions just in that very small and limited sample. So that gives you some indication of the real crisis and the constraint on economic development that is staring our region in the face. Regional trends may be quite different for a variety of reasons-sometimes for historic, geographic and cultural reasons. For example, in the Illawarra our close proximity to a booming Sydney labour market in more recent times has had a significant impact on the ability of local firms to attract suitable applicants. In 2001, according to the census data, 17 per cent of employed people in the Illawarra region commuted outside our region for work. That had grown from only three per cent in 1981. WhatI am trying to say is that regional skills shortage problems have a variety of underlying causes and a multifaceted strategy is needed to address this situation. The problem that we have locally is not just that we do not have enough skilled workers as a result of a general shortage of skills but also that we have an inability to recruit skills that are required locally because the labour market is competitive and often more attractive wages and conditions take labour out of the region. Through the creation of a local task force in the Illawarra, we are attempting to look at the areas of current and future skills shortages and trying to tackle those through a variety of responses. I urge the federal government to be sympathetic to any applications that come from our region for assistance in conducting a proper analysis and audit so that we can base our responses on the actual problems that we identify locally. Currently, our work is being assisted by the efforts of the Illawarra Regional Information Service and some of the work that it is undertaking for the regional development board. But what seems quite clear in our area is that the shortages are evident not just in the traditional blue-collar trades but also in a number of white-collar employment areas as well. The overall picture in the Illawarra is that most skilled labour is now in short supply relative to demand. I will list the occupations with the most critical shortages to give you feel of the problems that are emerging: aged care nurses and carers, boilermakers, chefs, electricians, engineers, fitters and turners and truck drivers. So it is not just in the traditional trade areas, where it is so obvious at the national level, that the acute crisis is emerging but also across a range of very important occupations that service community needs. In the time that I have left I want to say that, disappointingly, the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 does nothing to instil any confidence in me that the government is on top of this crisis which is going to impact on economic performance and productivity. Failure to invest in the development of human capital and skill development is going to be a major constraint on future economic growth. Twenty-four new TAFE colleges to duplicate existing TAFE courses will not address the problem in any meaningful long-term sense. The severe skills shortage that a number of people have addressed in their contributions in this debate has developed while the government has been asleep on its watch. It can blame no-one but itself. I think the bill before us this evening confirms that the government has no coherent strategy or coherent plan to tackle the crisis at the national level and to assist regions MAIN COMMITTEE like mine that are now facing the constraint of skill shortages. Businesses are running up against that constraint, and the government has no solution to address that problem. My plea is for the government to support innovative solutions at a regional level and provide assistance and resources to local organisations, be they task forces, community groupings or the area consultative committees-whatever framework exists at the local level-to try and analyse and address what is and is going to be a critical problem. (Time expired) and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 for a number of reasons, first and foremost because it does go to the heart of a lot of the issues that I have been concerned about throughout my working life both in this place and prior to coming to the national capital. Secondly, I am pleased because it also affords me the opportunity to talk about the general issue of skills shortages. There has been a lot said over the last couple of months on the ageing of the population and the resulting crisis that may occur in our society at various levels, whether it be in health expenditure, the ageing of the work force or work force participation. Along with the member for Gorton-I have to keep reminding myself of that change-I sit on a House of Representatives parliamentary committee which at this very moment is looking at the issues of work force participation. Many of the issues that have been raised by the Productivity Commission, the Minister for Workforce Participation and even the Victorian state government in one of its submissions, which I will refer to, are issues that we are very much aware of. There is a skills gap and a need to entice more people into the work force. Nowhere is that more evident than in the traditional trades. This does give me a good opportunity to speak about some of those issues without going into the outcomes of our parliamentary committee, as it is still early days. But I will reflect on at least one or two points that have crystallised in my mind from some of the evidence that I have read. Vocational training was rightly a key election issue throughout Australia, arguably no more so than in my electorate of Deakin in Victoria. The blue-collar trades are of critical importance, I guess regardless of where one resides. There is always a substantial number of bluecollar trades, even though we may feel at times that it is in dramatic decline. As I travel throughout my electorate I am fortunate enough to witness enthusiastic tradespeople of all ages contributing to our economy and our society in an important and worthy way. The tradeand vocation-bashing days of the Hawke-Keating era are thankfully behind us. There is more and more talk about valuing a trade and the alternative career path that young people take to the one which was promoted vigorously during the eighties and nineties-namely, going on to university. As I said, the Productivity Commission draft report came down recently with a series of comments about the ageing work force. It did identify issues to do with the ageing work force. One of the things that have come out from some of the evidence that I have seen is the notion that by 2020 there will be 500,000 jobs in Australia with no-one to fill them. I do not make any judgment about where those jobs are, but because of the sheer size of that figure, and it being only about 15 years away, it certainly concerns me that we could very well have 500,000 jobs with no-one to fill them. It alarms me particularly if they are in areas where we are currently relying on older workers to fill jobs, such as in the trades. The Victorian government, in a report they brought out recently called Preparing for Victoria’s future: challenges and opportunities in an ageing population, say: MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Barresi (Deakin) (5.58 P.m.)
theText: I am pleased to speak on the Vocational EducationWith fewer young people entering the labour force, it will be increasingly important that all young people gain the skills and training needed to participate in employment. In order to support future growth and the productivity of our labour force, education and training for young people will need to focus on the development of higher skill levels and the types of skills necessary to support new and emerging industries. That might very well be the case, but we also should not neglect the traditional industries out there that are crying out for people to go into them-that is, the trade areas. While I welcome that kind of statement from the Victorian government, I also note that one of the other comments they came up with in their report is about apprenticeships for the group of people aged 25 years or over. The report says: In the five years to 2003 commencements of New Apprentices for people aged 25 years and over grew from 9 700 to 52 000, an increase of 435 per cent. Over half ... of commencing Victorian New Apprentices in 2003 were aged 25 or over. There is an argument there to encourage people to go into apprenticeships at a more mature age rather than simply at school age levels. The Herald Sun also commented earlier this year that in Victoria there are hundreds of apprenticeships that are not being filled by school leavers. Training organisations blame this on a bias towards universities and low pay for apprentices. The school curriculum is targeted towards higher education. We have all known this for many years. I am pleased to see that there is a change of attitude taking place in the community and also at the legislative level. The growth of vocationally based employment since 1996, contrary to what the member for Throsby said, is an achievement of which this government can rightly be proud. The sector has been reinvigorated, and the number of people in New Apprenticeships has grown to almost 416,000. This number is three times that of 1995. Complementing this is a growth in vocational education and training. Minister Nelson highlighted recently that the most recent figures showed there were close to 1.7 million students in VET in 2002. Significantly, this represents over 10 per cent of Australia’s working age population. So we have seen some considerable movement, and we have really only seen it because of the concentration on vocational education by this government. One of the most memorable experiences of the recent election campaign was visiting the Eastern Industry Education Partnership in Ringwood with Minister Nelson to discuss vocational education with local trainees. It was heartening to see young people-many dressed in their overalls-brimming with pride and enthusiasm that they actually got into the trade of their choice, that they actually had a job, that they were learning some skills.
