You could see the self-esteem that was emerging in these young people-a sense of self-worth and a belief that they were on a path to a fulfilling career. It is this growing willingness in young people that underpins this government’s commitment to developing vocational training opportunities. The key to future development in vocational education and training is to work directly with industry. The federal government provides $510 million in incentives each year to employers to provide opportunities to new apprentices. I am pleased that the most recent trend in funding through the National Skills Shortages Strategy is continuing. Central to this is the $2 million this year and the $4 million for each future year to tackle shortages in traditional trades such as those of carpenters, plumbers and electricians. At March 2004, 35 per cent of new apprentices-147,000 of them-were in training in the traditional trades. MAIN COMMITTEE I find it a little ironic that the federal Labor Party are now beginning to squib for some moral high ground on this issue. The fact remains clear that it was Labor policy that set Australia on the course towards a skills shortage. The member for Throsby stated outright that she believes it is a failure of this government. Skills shortages do not happen overnight. They build up over successive years, and in fact sometimes can take a generation to occur. What we see is very much the culmination of the fact that previous governments ignored the issue and placed the full emphasis on tertiary education for our young people. The fact remains clear that it was Labor policy that set Australia on the course towards a skills shortage. High unemployment created an initial shortage of places for blue-collar workers. It is fraudulent of the ALP to feign interest in vocational education. I am sure the members opposite remember how the Minister for Education, Science and Training would often entice the member for Jagajaga, the shadow minister in this area, to ask a question on vocational education. He would stand at the dispatch box and urge the member for Jagajaga: ‘Please ask me a question on vocational education.’ This happened throughout the last term. In fact, you could probably count on one hand the number of questions that the member for Jagajaga asked in this area in the three-year period. Now we have come into parliament this term and there is this new-found interest in vocational education and having a hit at the government. Of course, complicit in this fraudulent concern for vocational education are the state ALP governments. In December 2003 the state and territory Labor governments rejected the federal government’s $3.6 billion offer for a new ANTA agreement, a real increase of 2.5 per cent per annum. This represented the state governments walking away from 71,000 additional VET places over three years. They basically turned their backs on the agreement and in doing so turned their backs on 71,000 additional places. The decisions of the state and territory Labor governments highlight the deficiencies of the ANTA agreement. The federal government applied the additional funding offered through ANTA to purchase additional training places for priority groups such as older workers and disabled workers. However, the federal funding for vocational education and training should not need to be administered in such an ad hoc fashion and at the whim and the mercy of state governments who play politics with all Commonwealth funding, no matter what the policy area may be. Melbourne’s eastern suburbs area, irrespective of it being snubbed by the Latham election bandwagon and the Bracks Labor government, continues to be a desirable place for people to live. It remains a strong growth corridor where an increasing number of families require an appropriate mix of training opportunities. Prosperity, however, creates challenges and, rather than meeting these, the ANTA system has failed our local area. I would like to share with this House a real example of how the ANTA funding has failed the people in the electorate of Deakin in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne, particularly in terms of the deficiencies of ANTA’s funding distribution process. I would like to refer members to a very significant government school in my electorate, one which I am certainly proud of: the Ringwood Secondary College. It is a good government school with strong enrolments; it is a strong state government school with a proud history. In fact, it celebrated its 50th anniversary earlier this year, and I was pleased to take the Prime Minister to the school for its celebrations. The school and its principal, Mr Michael Phillips, MAIN COMMITTEE saw a valuable opportunity to establish an automotive and manufacturing skills centre to assist students throughout the eastern suburbs to obtain an accessible vocational education. Naturally the first step for the school was to apply for capital funding from ANTA. I was particularly confident-they had a great submission-that their proposal would be successful. Skills shortages were starting to bite in the region as more and more experienced tradesmen were leaving their fields. In fact, the local ACC, Jobs East, back in the early years when I first got elected, did a needs analysis on skills shortages in the area and showed that in the metals industry, the traditional trades, there was a huge gap in people taking up opportunities. The demand for the labour was greater than the supply. You would think that a proposal by a local school which would help fix the skills gap would be welcomed by ANTA. You would also think that the submission would be supported by the Bracks government, who after all do believe that they should be supporting the eastern suburbs, even though their actions do not prove that. The fact is the Ringwood Secondary College was unsuccessful. Not only did the school miss out; not one application for ANTA funding in the eastern suburbs was successful-not one from any of the schools in the entire eastern region, which of course makes up 40 per cent of Melbourne’s manufacturing base. In appraising what were wrong, it became blatantly clear that the ANTA funding allocation process was flawed. On closer inspection it was evident that successful applicants were located in traditional Labor heartland areas, particularly in Melbourne’s western suburbs. has put forward, that would provide funding for the Ringwood Secondary College to provide this excellent training that the member for Deakin asserts is necessary? dorothy dixer, and I will get to the point. Yes, not only is the skills centre funded by the federal government, but it is funded in collaboration with the employers the Eastern Industry Education Partnership Group, which looks after young kids in the school. The workshop will be located at the Ringwood Secondary College. The interesting thing is that they have now introduced one other skill, and that is robotics in the manufacturing technology. So you have automotive skills, manufacturing technology and robotics. You have an organisation like ANCA, which is a precision technology organisation; you have AAA, which is the largest manufacturer of airconditioners for the motor vehicle industry; and you have a number of other organisations all in partnership with Ringwood Secondary College. But it is not only for the benefit of that college. Because they will be providing the training for other government schools and, Member for Denison, independent schools in the area, it will include everyone. It is embracing employers, government and non-government schools and those who are charged with finding jobs for young people. SoI am very pleased that has taken place-and, of course, not with any help from the ANTA funding process or, can I say, from the Bracks government. The federal government does allocate its funding to the states and territories in accordance with a funding act. ANTA was established to set up planning, accountability and funding arMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Kerr
theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek to intervene.
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: The Deputy Speaker ( Mr Causley)
theText: Is the member for Deakin willing to give way?
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Barresi
theText: Yes.
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Kerr
theText: Is there anything in this bill, or is there any other measure that the government
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Barresi
theText: I will be very pleased to elaborate to the member for Denison on thatrangements for VET programs. The experience of Ringwood Secondary College demonstrates that the organisation is flawed. In particular, ANTA is a hindrance to effective planning for future vocational programs. The partisan agenda of the Victorian Bracks Labor government ignored future trade workers in and around my electorate. Significantly, the sad bevy of local state Labor members, many of whom of course were not expecting to be in parliament, has been quiet on the issue, and they have failed to effectively represent the eastern suburbs. I for one have no faith whatsoever in the Bracks government or any of the Labor governments meeting their obligations under ANTA. It has been a dishonest approach by that government, and unmet promises have left many Victorians high and dry. SoI am pleased that this particular project has got up and running. Skill shortages do not occur overnight, as I mentioned. The biggest crisis facing the trade sector is a lack of incoming skilled workers to replenish the work force as experienced workers retire. I certainly recall speaking with many secondary school students in Deakin who described how a failure stigma can follow young school leavers who pursue a blue-collar career. For many parents of my generation, the old state technical school system was an effective system which produced school leavers of the necessary skills and enthusiasm to pursue a trade apprenticeship. I appreciate that we cannot wholeheartedly go back to that system, but I do look forward to the increased concentration by governments of all persuasions at the state and federal level-and even the community-on placing greater value and greater emphasis on trade qualifications. This bill is a first step towards achieving that. The abolishment of ANTA in July 2005 is the second step. Certainly, I believe the creation of the trade colleges is a most welcomed addition to valuing the trade areas and also giving real hope and aspiration to young people who are looking at alternative career paths. I welcome the upcoming negotiation of the 2005 ANTA agreement, and I welcome the changes that the minister will be introducing in the next six months. for Deakin’s contribution. I am happy to also acknowledge his interest. He is one of the very few government members who show an interest. Of course, he was Chairman of the House of Representives Standing Committee on Employment and Workplace Relations and I was a member of that committee, and I think it is fair to say that, as chair, he certainly conducted himself well. He certainly showedterm he was chair. He showed an interest. SoI suppose it therefore makes it all the more difficult for him to have to get up and defend the government. Because for him to actually get up and boast that one of the great things about this government is that it has abolished ANTA, that it has not supplied the TAFE places required, is an unfortunate thing. It is an unfortunate thing for someone who I believed had a passionate and sincere interest in vocational training. Therefore the government has really placed the member for Deakin in an unenviable position: to have to get up and justify these very crude decisions by this government. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Brendan O’connor (Gorton) (6.17 P.m.)
theText: I am happy to rise after the member
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Barresi
theText: Was?
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Brendan O’connor
theText: I am hoping he is back for this term, but certainly lastHowever, I rise to lament, as I know other Labor members have lamented, the decline in skills in this country-the skills that have certainly declined since 1996. I accept the contention by the member for Deakin that there were shortages during the Hawke-Keating period. There were shortages, and I will refer to some of those shortages. But I think, when they win four elections in a row, it is about time the government accept that not only are they the government for this term but they take some responsibility for the preceding three terms. It seems to me that they want to carry on and continue to blameMr Kerr interjectingconsider all things good to be of their own design, whereas of course we know that they are the beneficiaries of many of the policies of the Hawke-Keating period. When the government are in their fourth term, I think it is important for them to start to accept some responsibility for their failures. On occasions in this place I have criticised, with qualification, I accept, some of the deficiencies of the Hawke-Keating period because there were some. I think, in general, there were more better things done than worse things. There were mistakes, we made them and we have acknowledged them. But this government fail to ever accept any responsibility or acknowledge their own failings. A division having been called in the House of RepresentativesSitting suspended from 6.20 p.m. to 6.38 p.m. that governments and government members have a responsibility to accept mistakes and failings and to try to rectify them. Unfortunately, it seems that this government wants to continue to blame any fault or any problem with the system, including vocational training, on Labor governments that ended their time in 1996. I think it is important that the government owns up to its own failings. There is no doubt there is a major skills shortage in this country, and it is something that we have to rectify. As we know, before the election, Labor was promoting the idea of increasing TAFE places in order to meet some of those shortages. Unfortunately, the fact that Labor failed to be elected meant that that was never going to occur. But I think it is now important for the government to announce what it wants to do to sort out some of these major problems. As I said earlier, there were skills shortages in the Hawke-Keating period, but the shortage trend has continued over the last eight-year period. The Department of Employment and Workplace Relations estimates trade shortages in construction, engineering and automotive trades, but also indicates that there are many shortages in the area of specialised skills. Some trade occupations have remained consistently in shortage for long periods of time. The department says that trade occupations which have been in short supply for a number of years include pastry cooks, chefs and motor vehicle mechanics continuously from 1994; tool makers and upholsterers continuously from 1995; boilermakers, fitters and turners, metal machinists, pressure welders and sheet metal workers in all but one or two years since 1995; refrigeration and air conditioning mechanics continuously from 1998; panel beaters, vehicle painters and automotive electricians continuously from the end of 1998. We have many skills shortages in our labour market. I will add another. I think the Deputy Leader of the Opposition raised this and it has been raised in question time. We have a critical shortage of bricklayers. I suppose one could say it is nice to see a bricklayer make $100,000 a year. We are probably in MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Brendan O’connor
theText: Indeed. As the member for Denison suggests, they clearly
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Brendan O’connor
theText: Before the suspension, I was making mention of the factthe wrong game, Mr Deputy Speaker! But I think that points to a real problem in the workplace; it points to a real shortage. Two of the occupations which have not been mentioned perhaps as often and for which I think demand is going to grow exponentially over time are those of child carers and aged carers. Whatever the occupational description, those caring and learning industries represent large areas and involve particular skills. We do have a shortage of child carers. One of the reasons for that is that it is market driven. The wage or salary of a child carer is so low that many qualified child carers choose to just get out, because a career in that field is just not worth pursuing if you want to pay for a mortgage-increasingly a more expensive mortgage relative to income-or to do other things. There are real problems in child care. As we know, there is an increasing demand for aged care workers. Again, I think that is a very low-paid occupation commensurate with the skills and responsibilities required of those workers. We really have to turn our minds to that. In the Australian Industry Group’s recently released skills policy statement, entitled Worldclass skills for world-class industries, which was presented in August this year, it was highlighted that Australia faces a skills crisis in the next five years as the existing work force retires and the number of new tradespersons is insufficient to fill the gap. Labour supply problems are being experienced in many industry sectors but those that have heavily relied upon the traditional apprenticeship system as the major means of recruiting and skilling new entrants have experienced greater difficulties in sourcing skilled labour. In a survey of more than 760 manufacturers, entitled ‘Australia’s skills gap-costly, wasteful and widespread’, the AiG found that one in two firms were experiencing difficulties in obtaining skilled labour. The greatest difficulties were in metal based sectors, particularly for transport equipment manufacturers. High levels of difficulty in finding skilled labour were also evident in the machinery and equipment, fabricated metals and basic metal manufacturing sectors. Across manufacturing overall, there were 21.8 vacancies per 1,000 workers. The highest vacancy rates for skilled labour were in the wood, wood products and furniture sector, which had about 45 vacancies per 1,000 employees, and in the machinery and equipment sector, which had nearly 38 vacancies per 1,000 employees. All other metal based sectors had very high vacancy rates. What that report points to, in quantifiable terms, is that there is a major skills shortage in many occupational groups in this nation. The AiG estimated that the national skills shortage was 21,000 positions and that filling these positions would deliver a fivefold increase in the number of new people employed in manufacturing over the last 12 months. The largest numbers of skills shortages were in the areas of chemicals, petroleum and coal products; transport equipment; and machinery and equipment-each with estimated shortages of at least 3,000 positions. One report after another confirms the assertion I am making-indeed the contention that the opposition is making-that we have a fundamental problem. It is not being acknowledged by the government. I do not know how they work this out, but they believe there is a nexus between the HawkeKeating period and the skills shortage in 2004, and they do not want to turn their minds to fixing the problem. There is a further report. A discussion paper was commissioned by the Dusseldorp Skills Forum amidst concerns over the growing shortage in trade skills. It was presented at a round table convened in July 2003 by Group Training Australia. It presents new data on long-run MAIN COMMITTEE apprentice training rates by broad occupation groups. The data show a significant and sustained decline in the training rate over the last 10 years. The author of this report discusses the implications of this decline and provides an overview and assessment of the key explanations. I would advise members who have not come across that report to do so because it does provide some of the reasons why there have been these shortages and suggests policy recommendations to address the decline. In short, these recommendations include training levies, an increase in public sector training, changes to employer incentives, improving the quality of operations of group training companies, re-establishing pre-apprenticeship programs, improving VET in Schools, improving multiemployer coordination, increasing innovation intensity of industry and improving marketing of apprenticeships. Those are some of the things the author of that report points to as what we could be doing to fix the problem of the critical skills shortages we have in the labour market. Instead of looking at some of these things, this government has been blaming others. It has been blaming the states-and, as we know, a favourite hobby of the Commonwealth government is to blame either previous federal Labor governments or, indeed, current state Labor governments for the Commonwealth’s failing. It is either doing that or not making much headway in this area. If announcing the abolition of ANTA is supposed to be some sort of beneficial reform, I do not see it. What it does say to me is that it is perhaps a symbolic exercise in what this government really thinks about vocational training. We in the Labor Party were the creators of ANTA in 1992. We were the ones who supported ANTA and promoted the idea of vocational training. This government have paid lipservice to the notion of vocational training. There are shortages of training places. As a result, there are shortages of skills in the labour market. The government need to focus on those deficiencies. If they do not listen to the ACTU then they should listen to the employers, if that is what they wish to do. If they are not willing to look at a survey that might be commissioned by the ACTU, because of their ideological blindness to the reality of what is going on, they should listen to the employers. The major peak employer bodies are saying there are major skills shortages. Most employers are not sitting around talking about the need to make laws unfair for employees in the areas of termination; they are talking about skills shortages and asking what the government will be doing to fix them. There is not a great amount of detail on the duplication of technical colleges, which was announced during the election campaign. I do not want to be negative, but it seems to me that it was an announcement for election campaign purposes. On the face of it, it does not seem to be particularly practical. We are going to have a TAFE system and, standing beside that, these Commonwealth technical colleges. Instead of funding the TAFE system that exists, the Commonwealth is now going to divert energy into a separate system so that they will run concurrently but separately. That does not seem, on the face of it, to be a very wise thing to do. As I understand it, it is going to be some time before those colleges are up and running. As I understand it from the proposal of the Prime Minister during the election campaign, one of those colleges is proposed to be in or around my electorate, in Sunshine. I share the suburb of Sunshine, a great working-class suburb of Melbourne, with the member for Maribyrnong-I am not sure which one of us is supposed to be the beneficiary of this college. It will be a learning institution and, if it is at all effective, constituents of mine and, indeed, of the member for Maribyrnong and of other members will obviously be able to use it. I have to MAIN COMMITTEE say that my electorate and surrounding electorates do need more places. There needs to be more support for many of our constituents. If you look at the average levels of unemployment or of skills, I think the electorate of Gorton probably is not as well favoured as other places. It is a great place, it has a great pride and it is a great community to represent, but perhaps it has not been afforded the same opportunities as other places. People do not complain-they get on with it-but it would be great to see money funnelled in there to provide the wherewithal to ensure that my constituents and their children will be able to be properly trained up for full-time employment. Having said that, I am not convinced that the way to go about it is to set up this separate system which will not rectify the fundamental problems we have. Indeed, it will detract from the focus that I think the Commonwealth needs to have upon the TAFE system. It seems to me that it is going to be robbing TAFE to fund these ‘you-beaut’ tech colleges. I will accept whatever works. As the member for Gorton, representing people who I am sure would delight in more resources going into the area, I am not ideologically predisposed to one particular design or the other. But I do think that the system has to be coordinated, and I do think the Commonwealth have to start being a little bit more mature in the area. Instead of blaming the states, they should be working with them. Instead of failing to reach agreement on ANTA with the state governments, they should be showing some leadership, moving forward and reaching agreement. If they were to do that, they would have my respect-if not my entire agreement on the way in which they proceed. So there are some significant problems, as I have outlined over the last 20 minutes or so. In so many areas and occupational groups there are deficiencies, and those deficiencies have been cited by employer groups. I would have thought the government would listen to those employer groups when they shout from the rooftops that they have major problems employing people in particular areas because of those skill shortages. tion and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004. The purpose of this bill is to amend the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992 to appropriate a total of $1.15 billion as the Australian government’s contribution to the delivery of vocational education and training in 2005 and to adjust the currently legislated funding limit for 2004 to reflect the outcome of the ANTA agreement negotiations for that year. This bill supports the Australian government’s plans for a smooth transition to new arrangements for VET funding to be put in place from July 2005. The Australian government is committed to maximising vocational education and training opportunities for our youth and continues to deliver real results for the 70 per cent of school leavers who do not go directly to university from school. A hallmark feature of Australia’s highly successful VET system is the growth of new apprenticeships and their diffusion through the work force. Since 1995, when Labor was last in government, the number of new apprenticeships has increased by 195 per cent to over 416,800 in training as at the end of March 2004. Last year, there were 2,300 new apprentices in Dobell, compared with 650 new apprentices in 1995 when Labor was last in government. That stands in stark contrast to the comments of the previous speaker. This growth in new apprentices is in direct response to the needs of industry for skilled workers. The evidence of the program’s success is staggering. Employers are embracMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Ticehurst (Dobell) (6.53 P.m.)
theText: I rise today in support of the Vocational Educaing higher skill levels, with 85 per cent of all new apprentices in training participating at certificate III level or higher. Since 1996, the number of women in VET has grown by 30 per cent to 812,900. The number of Indigenous students has grown by 85 per cent over the same period. Forty-three per cent of VET clients are now in rural and regional Australia. The growth in new apprenticeships has been the strongest for people aged 40 years and over, where the numbers have increased almost sevenfold in the last six years. This is a great achievement. The reskilling of mature age workers helps to position industry to address the labour force challenges of the future. The VET in Schools program is also working well. In 2002, over 185,500 students were participating in VET in Schools. In fact, the number of school students undertaking training has grown by 97 per cent since 1997, reflecting the huge success of the VET in Schools program, which is now available to more than 95 per cent of Australian technical schools. In fact, at the Wadalba high school in my electorate, 84 students in year 11 are involved in VET programs. That is quite an achievement. Next year that school will be doing year 12 for the first time. The coalition has introduced school based new apprentices and there are more than 14,000 in training today. However, while there has been great interest in service industries, such as hospitality, tourism and business, there has been less growth in school based new apprenticeships in the trades. The coalition is providing $17.9 million over four years to help a further 4,000 school students get into school based new apprenticeships in the trades through group training. Our local work force reaps the benefit from having school leavers ready for work duties, and the only way this can happen is through good policy and strong partnerships between government, educational institutions, training organisations-like Central Coast Group Training, which does a fantastic job locally-and local businesses. The Central Coast campus of the University of Newcastle has been working hard to expand the VET opportunities for its students. The Australian government has an integrated and comprehensive plan to ensure that the value of trades is enhanced as a career path. This includes providing expanded opportunities for students wanting a career in the trades, better advice on career opportunities, greater financial assistance for new apprentices and industry initiatives to build our skills base of the future. In fact, in my electorate of Dobelltraining scheme has been quite successful. They have over 400 apprentices on the local Central Coast involved with many of the businesses. Also, the local Central Coast manufacturers group hosted a meeting of school advisers from all the secondary schools to give them an opportunity to understand where the skill shortages are in the trades. This is a practical way in which people can be involved. One of the most significant boosts to vocational education and training ever undertaken by the government was announced by the Prime Minister in his election commitments. He announced various measures to address industry skill shortages, including the establishment of 24 technical colleges throughout Australia, and one to service the MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Albanese
theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek to intervene.
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: The Deputy Speaker ( Mr Quick)
theText: Is the member for Dobell willing to give way?
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Ticehurst
theText: No. I wish to continue with my speech. In my local area, the groupCentral Coast. These technical schools are actually years 11 and 12. They are not competing with TAFE in any way, as members opposite would have us believe. This is great news for the electorate of Dobell and for Australia. It is wonderful that we can have an Australian government that is achieving record results when it comes to vocational education and training yet is committed to providing even more funding to VET to further maximise opportunities for our kids. The 24 Australian technical colleges will be created in regions suffering serious skill shortages and high rates of youth unemployment and which are supported by a significant or rapidly growing industry base. The abolition of technical colleges by the states has meant that over the past few decades our young people have lacked training and skills. These pathways would have been provided particularly to the 70 per cent who do not go directly from school to university. The price we have paid is the current severe skill trade shortages we are experiencing in many of our key industries. The colleges will provide tuition for up to 300 students in years 11 and 12 and offer both academic and vocational education to students while completing their school studies. Earlier this year the Howard government also announced the provision of a Commonwealth Trade Learning Scholarship to enable new apprenticeships in skill shortage trades. The scholarships will provide $500 to new apprentices starting their apprenticeship on or after 1 July 2005 at the end of the first and second years of the new apprenticeship. The initiative will assist around 60,000 firstand secondyear new apprentices from year 1, July 2005. Many new apprentices eligible for a Commonwealth Trade Learning Scholarship will also be eligible for an $800 tool kit which the coalition government will provide to new apprentices in areas of trade skill shortage. The Howard government has taken a leadership role in determining the overall direction and strategies to develop a skilled Australian work force. Skill shortages are always of concern to industry, but, as you can see, the government is committed to providing record funding levels toward VET initiatives to address this. Industry is increasingly recognising that an investment in skills is critical to its bottom line. As a result of the coalition government’s investment in training and direct assistance to employers of new apprentices, Australian employers are spending more on training their employees than ever before. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, employers are spending 52 per cent more on training than they were in 1996. The Australian government’s vocational education and training program continues to go from strength to strength and is in stark contrast to the poor VET results of the Australian Labor Party. As I mentioned earlier, new apprenticeships have increased by over 195 per cent since Labor was in government. However, this is not the only evidence of Labor’s lack of commitment to the provision of vocational training opportunities. When the Howard government offered a new ANTA agreement to the states and territories in May last year, every state and territory rejected our offer of an additional $220 million of funding for the creation of thousands of new training places. To keep good faith, the government applied the funding which was not taken up by the states and territories to purchase a total of 75,000 training places for priority groups. These are older workers, parents returning to work and people with disabilities. In this way the Australian government has fully maintained its level of commitment to vocational education and training in 2004 despite a lack of cooperation from federal and state Labor. MAIN COMMITTEE We have announced new measures in our election commitments to a total value of $1.06 billion over four years. This is one of the largest boosts to vocational education and training undertaken by any government. These new measures include extending youth allowance to new apprentices who are currently not eligible to receive youth allowance, even though they undertake studies while they are employed. This contrasts with the situation for university students. They are enabled to combine study and work while retaining their entitlement to youth allowance and Austudy within current eligibility requirements. The coalition government will provide a further $5 million over three years in residential assistance to new apprentices who have to move away from their family home in order to start or continue a new apprenticeship. The coalition will provide funding for prevocational training, which is a prerequisite for many businesses. This will provide apprentices with basic skills in the workplace, including familiarity with tools and simple work practices, before they work as new apprentices. It is disappointing that over recent years the states and territories have been slashing places in prevocational training in the trades, limiting opportunities for young people to get a step up into a trade. The coalition government will provide $35.5 million over four years to more than double the new apprenticeship access program, which gives participants assistance with basic literacy and numeracy, employability skills and other relevant work and trade skills. The Australian government has played and will continue to play a leadership role in the overall direction and strategies needed to develop a skilled Australian work force. Funding under the VET Funding Act in 1995 was $77.9 million. For 2005 under this bill the government will be spending $1.148 billion, underpinning the nation’s strong economic growth and low unemployment. Since coming to power this government has revived Australia’s vocational education and training system. The numbers in training have grown from 1.27 million in 1995 to over 1.72 million-an increase of 35 per cent. The number of new apprenticeships has grown by 195 per cent to span over 500 different occupations. New apprenticeships are vital to ensure the future economic prosperity of my local region and of our nation. The continuing financial support for the training of new apprenticeships is provided for in the bill presently before the House. I urge members opposite to support this important piece of legislation. tion and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 and want to acknowledge at the outset the great privilege that I had in the previous term thanks to the decision of the then Leader of the Opposition, the member for Hotham, in appointing me shadow minister for employment services and training. The opportunity to be involved in vocational education and training took me to every state and territory, where I was able to discuss the challenges facing Australia in providing a skilled work force and also to talk first-hand to a great many Australians who were providing that vocational training in schools, in TAFEs, in private training organisations and in group training organisations. This issue is also one that I raised continually in the last parliament. Only when the federal election was upon us were skills shortages-which had been created as a direct result of government policy-acknowledged by the government. Before then it was clear that everyone, from peak business organisations to financial journalists and the Governor of the Reserve Bank, had been talking about Australia’s emerging skills crisis and its potential to threaten MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Albanese (Grayndler) (7.05 P.m.)
theText: I am pleased to speak to the Vocational Educafuture economic growth. According to Group Training Australia, there are currently national skills shortages in all key trades, including the engineering trades, all the vehicle trades, all the construction trades, all the food trades, as well as the electrical trades, electronics, printing, the wood trades, hairdressing and furniture upholstery. Service industries such as nursing, child care and teaching are also desperate for new entrants, to keep up with demand. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry in its July 2004 survey of investor confidence found that for the first time in 14 years the availability of suitably qualified employees was the No. 1 constraint on future investment decisions. Specifically, 79 per cent of firms surveyed said recruiting employees with appropriate skills was a major or moderate concern. In September the Australian Industry Group released its survey, which found that more than one in two manufacturing firms were experiencing difficulties finding the skilled workers they needed. According to the Australian Industry Group, the skills crisis was here and now. The government’s own department, in the DEWR skilled vacancy index for August, found that vacancies for tradespersons had reached the highest level since such data was collected. Unfortunately it is likely to get worse. Over the next five years 175,000 workers are expected to leave the traditional trades, with only 70,000 expected to enter. Due to this, the Labor Party established a Senate Employment, Workplace Relations and Education Committee inquiry into skills shortages-something that was opposed by the government because they said it was not an issue. Yet the committee found that a failure to have enough skilled metal, engineering and manufacturing workers to carry out the $20 billion worth of major infrastructure and resource projects expected in the next 10 years would threaten the very viability of those projects. Indeed, it has been estimated that current skills shortages could cost Australia $9 billion in lost output over the coming decade. The absurdity of this is that, at the same time that you have this shortage of skilled workers, you also have a significant reservoir of untapped labour. In particular, Labor identified and came up with a strategy to address the fact that 45,000 young people leave school early to go nowhere-not to go into further education, training or into a job. The Leader of the Opposition, Mark Latham, deserves a great deal of credit for being ahead of the game. As the centrepiece of his first budget reply, he announced the youth guarantee, a comprehensive approach to tackling skills shortages, addressing the needs of young people and providing them with those opportunities. That policy is not surprising, because that is part of a proud tradition of the Labor Party. It was the Whitlam Labor government in 1973 that first provided Commonwealth financial support for apprenticeships through the establishment of the National Apprenticeship Assistance Scheme. This scheme was a landmark for apprenticeships in Australia. It marked the beginning of what has been continuous Commonwealth funding for apprenticeships and ensured that they became a national priority. It was the Hawke Labor government in the 1980s that took on the states and territories and put in place new industrial arrangements that enabled the traineeship system to be created in the first place. It was the Keating Labor government that in 1992 got the agreement of all the states and territories to the establishment of the Australian National Training Authority. This was a statutory body which sought to overcome the inconsistencies of our federal structure and bring a national focus to the delivery of VET. But what we have seen over the last 8½ years of the Howard government is an undermining of this system, culminating in the announcement in a MAIN COMMITTEE press release-not during the election campaign-that ANTA would be abolished from July next year. It is absolutely outrageous that nothing about this issue was mentioned or put to the Australian people prior to the election on 9 October. But it is not surprising, because the whole structure of vocational training has been under attack. Indeed, since 1997, real funding per teaching hour has dropped by 19 per cent and the proportion of VET funding coming from the Commonwealth has fallen from 25 per cent to 22.2 per cent. So none of these arguments about the responsibility of the states stand; the Commonwealth has not been keeping up its share of the bargain. Inevitably, these cuts have undermined the quality of training that 1.72 million Australians are currently receiving from the VET sector. At a time when we most needed our federal structure to be working cooperatively, Minister Nelson went along to the ANTA negotiations last year. The states would not sign up because the offer had no growth funding in it and it had the government’s ideological industrial relations agenda attached to it, so the minister simply said, ‘I’ll get back to you next October after the election.’ He broke off negotiations. That is not surprising, given the decision after the election. The agreement was supposed to commence on 1 January this year, and the government could not even get its act together to get that in place. It also could not get its act together to have an ANTA CEO, because she resigned some months ago and was replaced by a temporary appointee. We all know now why that occurred, as well. With respect to the government’s much-vaunted New Apprenticeships scheme, we know that it has become a numbers driven operation. When the government says there has been a massive growth in new apprenticeships, we know that most of that growth has been in the higher volume, higher turnover industries, as a means to subsidise wage bills, not to provide adequate training in what most Australians would see an apprenticeship as being-that is, a combination of on-the-job and off-thejob training in a profession, be it white collar or blue collar, over a number of years. The government did announce at one stage during the election campaign-there was a leak in the Sydney Morning Herald-that skills shortages were going to spur a $725 million spree. What did we actually get? We got a tool box to fix the skills shortages. How out of touch! Obviously the government was not aware that construction, electrical, metal fabrication and other awards contain tool allowances of up to $22. If you add that up, you get an amount that is greater than $800. When I raised that with Steve Balzary, from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, he assured me that no employer out there would seek to have the tool allowance removed, even though they were having their tools provided for them. It was a very bold commitment indeed. The government also announced an $18 million plan for an institute for trade skill excellence. This was to provide ‘industry endorsement of qualifications provided by private and public training providers, including TAFE, identifying excellence and the preferred providers of high-quality and industry relevant training’. That was ANTA’s job. So they announced a replacement for a national body that has been doing the job and that involves employers, unions, TAFE and the federal-state relationship. They announced its replacement in a five-page document that did not mention the name ‘ANTA’ once. The institute will have four shareholders: ACCI, AiG, the Business Council of Australia and the NFF. The government said: ‘No TAFE, no unions, no state government. We will just have a focus on one section.’ The truth is MAIN COMMITTEE that employers and employees have an interest in a cooperative relationship when it comes to training, beyond any other policy area that you can think of. The tragedy is that, certainly in the time that I was the shadow minister for training, I had excellent relationships not just with the trade union movement but with ACCI and the Australian Industry Group. The member for Cunningham is here. I went down to the Illawarra with her and the member for Throsby and sat down with the Illawarra business community, unions, TAFE, training providers and local schools, who all had a common interest. That is the only way that this system works. Yet it is being undermined. As part of this policy announcement the government announced an industry reference group for each key trades industry. What are skills councils for? They are only just in the process of establishing them and they announce a duplication. As regards the proportion of the $18.3 million that is going to filter down-that is not going to ACCI and business organisations to create a bureaucracy-there are 20 awards for excellence valued at $10,000 each year, for three years. So $600,000 out of the $18.3 million is filtered down-to anybody. Awards are not a bad idea, but it is a pity that the government were not conscious of the way that the system was operating already. The government could not be bothered sending a representative to the world skills conference-a conference where 50,000 young people over three days in May this year went through the Brisbane Convention Centre. But, then again, during the campaign I spoke at the TAFE directors annual conference, a big national event. No government minister showed up; they sent along a parliamentary secretary. They could not be bothered during the election campaign to go along and talk to TAFE, the major provider of vocational education and training in this country. That is the heart of the system, and that is the reason why we were very committed to filling the gap, to providing extra TAFE places. Then we come to the government’s plan for ‘technical colleges’, as they call them. They cannot say where they will be, when they will be up and running, and whether or not they will charge fees. Last year, according to the ACCER, there were 415,000 senior secondary high school students in this country; 202,000 of them were doing VET in Schools. It is happening. The member for Dobell, who refused to answer a question, outlined quite well in some of his comments what is going on, on the ground, on the Central Coast of New South Wales. What is going on with schools, be they in Gladstone, Marrickville, the Central Coast of New South Wales, Salisbury in Adelaide or Alice Springs, is that they are linking up with TAFE and local industry and providing an integrated vocational education and training system. It is occurring. Why you would come up with a gimmick, when we have a serious policy issue to confront, is beyond me. The government senators’ report-the Liberal senators’ response, not the ALP’s responsefrom the Senate skills inquiry stated, on page 216: ... VET in Schools ... is already active in promoting partnerships between the three education sectors, industry and the local community. There is, in any event, limitations on the Commonwealth in facilitating and promoting these partnerships which are best handled at state level. No wonder the member for Page-who in a personal explanation today did not question the issue raised by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition-has called for the funding to go to Wollongbar TAFE, instead of having a college. I went to a TAFE college in his electorate during MAIN COMMITTEE the election campaign, and they are providing a world-class system but they are starved of funds. What does it say to the 202,000 young Australians who are currently engaged in VET in Schools? Indeed, as a result of a reference from the current minister, the member for Bradfield, to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Education and Training, we had an inquiry into VET in Schools on this very issue. Did the government report say that we should do something about that? No. What it said was that we should do something about the costs, which is why Labor committed in its Youth Guarantee to paying all TAFE fees for VET in Schools students. This commitment looked after the 202,000 people rather than creating another bureaucracy that, sometime into the future at some unknown cost, might be able to have 7,000 students. It is an absurd duplication of resources. This government stands condemned for its lack of action in addressing skills shortages. Indeed, its policies have contributed to these skills shortages which seriously undermine Australia’s potential economic growth and rob Australians of the opportunity to participate in the work force. on the nature of the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 but also, and perhaps more importantly, to highlight what I regard as one of the most urgent economic challenges confronting Australia. It is a major issue that we have to confront in terms of working out how we attract investment for skilling, which will in turn attract investment from the private sector and create further jobs into the future. In that context I indicate at the outset that Labor supports this bill for one reason: to ensure grants to the vocational education sector for the coming year. That is pretty important. The last thing we should do is create any more barriers or difficulties for the vocational education sector at a time of major skills shortages in Australia. Having said that, it is worth noting that, whilst this bill is about funding, it in no way addresses the pressing issues in vocational education and training that need to be seriously debated in this place and in the broader community. I challenge the business sector to actually start to stand up and confront this government about its shortcomings and failings in relation to the economic challenges that confront Australia. I recall that, when Labor was in government, the business sector had a view on issues that were barriers to the future economic and social development of Australia. AllI can say is that since March 1996 there has been no leadership from the business sector in confronting Australia about its weaknesses and failings in the economic debate. All we hear about from key business representatives today is the need to make it easier to sack workers and keep their wages down. When do we really see them crying out about the fact that the Howard government has failed since March 1996, almost nine years, to do something about one of the major challenges confronting Australia, not only in the traditional trades but also in the professional area of employment-that is, how we train and skill people so that Australia continues to be competitive in a global world? I regard this as a most serious challenge to Australia. It is at a crisis point. The Howard government stands condemned for walking away from its responsibilities with respect to these fundamental issues. If we as a nation in the 21st century do not invest in education and training then we are basically failing ourselves and future generations, because we are creating barriers to investment and job creation in the future in a variety of sectors. I raise some important facts. Today there are nearly 22,000 unfilled vacancies for tradespersons in Australia. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Martin Ferguson (Batman) (7.26 P.m.)
theText: I rise to speak this evening not onlyThose 22,000 unfilled vacancies represent a barrier to attracting investment in Australia, both local and international. That effectively means that we are reducing employment in Australia because we do not have the skills to attract investment and give certainty to the private sector about a return on their investment. It is also estimated that skills shortages could cost the Australian economy $9 billion in lost output over the coming decade. And all we hear about from the Howard government is the agenda of creating jobs in Australia, which is not about investing in education and training but about trying to make it easier for disreputable employers to actually sack workers. That is their real agenda in confronting the economic challenges at this point in time. Having been the shadow minister for transport, infrastructure and regional development, I also note that $20 billion worth of major infrastructure and resource projects could be in jeopardy as a result of skills shortages primarily in trades and engineering areas. That speaks for itself. We also appreciate that cuts to public and private sector investment in skills formation in pursuit of productivity and efficiency gains have seriously eroded the skills base in crucial industries and occupations. That effectively means that the private sector has got to have a hard look at its own performance. Reducing investment in training and skilling is actually hindering its own future capacity to make profits. No employer in Australia should think that, by cutting expenditure on the skilling of their work force, they are doing the right thing by their shareholders in terms of maximising their economic opportunities in the future. I think that is something that the government has to have a look at. But some of our superannuation funds also have to have a look at it, because they are major investors in key projects in Australia. They have got to start speaking up about the fact that their potential investment return for workers through superannuation is being reduced by the failure of business generally to invest in the skilling which can potentially create bigger returns for their investments for the future. I also suggest to the House that, unfortunately, this skills shortage has gone unrecognised by the government, which has turned tens of thousands of young Australians away from TAFE each year. I also believe that we as a community have a problem. For far too long the community, not just the government, has had a view that the only way forward for young people is via university education. That is understandable because of the lack of opportunities for past generations, particularly for the children of the Depression-our own parents-who saw the opportunity of a university education as a step upwards. But the time has come for us to go out and, in a very positive way, promote the fact that doing an apprenticeship is no less an opportunity for young people than becoming a doctor, a lawyer, an optician or whatever. It is just as good to be an apprentice bricklayer, carpenter or chef. They are equally as important in terms of decent employment opportunities in Australia. That requires leadership at a national level. It requires us to work out a strategy in the Australian community to not only create additional TAFE places but sell the community the message that going to a TAFE and doing an apprenticeship is actually good for you as an individual, good for your family, good for your community and good for your nation. We have to confront it-we have failed ourselves-and it is equally as important as forcing the government’s hand in terms of putting real money into additional TAFE opportunities in the future. It is for that very reason that, to address the skills shortage, Labor at the last election promised to create some 36,000 new vocational education and training places each year and to pay MAIN COMMITTEE TAFE fees-and this is exceptionally important-for secondary students who want to get a vocational qualification. I want to underline the importance of not only putting additional TAFE places in place but also trying to encourage our young people to stay and complete years 11 and 12 and, in doing so, to have under their belts part completion of their apprenticeship so that they are more readily employable by employers willing to take on the responsibility of training young people in Australia. The more apprenticeships we can actually start at school to get our young people job ready and more attractive to employers so that they accept the responsibility of a full apprenticeship is very important not only to some of our suburbs, local communities and families but also to us in taking a big step forward as a community and overcoming the lack of skills in Australia. It is something we should be proud of. It is something that all state and local governments, in association with the private sector, ought to work in a cooperative and consultative way to achieve sooner rather than later. From manufacturing to science and engineering and in the health and education work forces, the availability of skilled people into the future to replace the baby boomers as they retire will fall far short of the levels required. We also have the problem with the ageing of the population. I am talking not just about the traditional trades such as bricklaying, the metal trades or whatever but also about other areas such as the service sector and aged care. The challenge will be to provide and fund training needs to actually meet growing demand and higher standards. We have heard the Treasurer bash on about the ageing of the Australian population in recent times. It is not just about how we pay for retirement but also about making sure we have the trained personnel in those aged care centres to look after the elderly citizens, who should be treated with respect and dignity in retirement. I go to the issue of technology and business processes. Changes are also driving additional training needs and new skill requirements in all areas of the work force. The Australian economy will be left behind if we fail to keep up and invest in our future. I have noted the fact that there are far fewer young people entering the work force to build a new skill base. It is well known that Australia’s productivity gains over the past two decades were stimulated by economic and labour market restructuring. They were initially put in place by the Hawke Labor government, which was elected in March 1983. When Labor came to government at that time, unemployment and inflation were both over 10 per cent, there was no economic growth and, in essence, there was an industrial war. Over the last two decades Australia has actually come off a very low base. It was what the Labor Party inherited when it was first elected in March 1983. The Australian community should not forget that. What is also accepted and perhaps less well recognised is the fact that the price we have paid as a result of reduced funding is a reduction in skills formation. According to the Productivity Commission, skills growth as a driver of productivity in Australia has dropped by 75 per cent over the last 10 years. And we talk about a nation that regards itself as being pretty productive. Our failure to invest in skills has actually reduced our productivity. In that context, I refer to the 2003 Senate report entitled Bridging the skills divide, which noted that the next wave of productivity gains will have to be founded on a new skills formation strategy. Where is that skills formation strategy? It is not in the tool box. It actually requires leadership at a senior government level. I wish it was only as easy as buying a tool box for a young person starting an apprenticeship, but it is far more complex. It actually requires the government to lead and work with state and territory governments and also to work in MAIN COMMITTEE partnership with the private sector, not the confrontationist approach that the Howard government is currently pursuing with its lack of a working relationship with the state TAFE sector and state and territory governments. To achieve that new skills strategy, I suggest to the House that we require increased public and private sector investment-that is, the government and private sector accepting responsibilities-as well as policy settings and a training delivery network that support new and more effective approaches to skills formation. Seems complex? It is not if you are actually prepared to work your way through those issues. That goes to the urgency of this issue. What is the Howard government’s answer? It was touched on by the member for Grayndler this evening. It is an approach intent on tinkering with a bureaucratic framework, not on delivering outcomes in the vocational education and training sector. I actually thought the establishment of ANTA was a historic moment for Australia. It meant actually getting the private sector, the representatives of workers, the union movement, and state and federal governments in the one room and working together with one common objective-to actually get more investment in the training of apprentices in Australia. I think the government’s proposal to abolish ANTA is short-sighted. I also believe that the proposal to establish 24 Australian technical colleges, mainly in-guess what: it sounds like the Regional Solutions Program-marginal coalition seats around the country is wrong. Let us take politics out of the issue of skilling in Australia and pursue in a very dogged way a commitment to actually do the right thing through cooperation, consultation and working together, rather than the Howard government’s desire to destroy the existing TAFE system. In that dogged pursuit of an industrial relations policy that is confrontationist, the Howard government is excluding the states and unions from any decision making about skilling in Australia, and that is also narrow-minded and short-sighted. We should not be ashamed of the VET sector. They have historically been good performers for Australia. We as a nation have prided ourselves in the past on our capacity to train people. Historically, a young tradesperson was able to go overseas and pick up a job anywhere because of the quality of the training through TAFE in Australia. Why would we destroy that? Because of the narrow ideological approach being pursued by the Howard government. You do not have to reinvent the wheel-you actually work to improve outcomes rather than destroy a proven system. I simply say that the proposal to establish a ministerial council of vocational education ignores the fact that the Commonwealth has-guess what-been unable to bring the states to the table to reach a new ANTA agreement. Why then-and this is a relevant question-if it cannot get the states to the table to work in a cooperative way and get a new ANTA agreement, would we accept that this government would be able to reach agreement through a ministerial council? It is not going to, because the government’s approach is basically: ‘Take it or leave it. We are dictating the terms. You do what you are told or you don’t get funding.’ I simply say that the proposals by the government are backward. They are not going to take us forward in our requirement to invest in training and skilling to create productivity and make Australia attractive for investment. Portability of qualifications across the nation is also important. There is no way we should destroy that. We fought too long at a national level in partnership with the private sector, unions and state governments in making some progress on the issue of portability. As we all know, it is also wrong that ANTA be re-established in the Department of Education, Science MAIN COMMITTEE and Training, where the short-term focus will be on establishing new administrative funding arrangements. This is bureaucracy and red tape gone mad. This government talks about its desire to assist small business. Frankly, all I can say is that it is going to make it far more complicated for small business. We have got good group training companies, good TAFE colleges and a desire by the Australian community to promote the apprenticeship system in Australia. The system is still attractive, but we need national leadership to reinforce more than ever to our young people as they go through years 10, 11 and 12 that there is a cooperative Commonwealth and state program aimed at attracting young people to do apprenticeships, because doing an apprenticeship is as good as training to be a doctor or a dentist. That is the message that has got to go out, in association with the addition of a national commitment to working with the state and territory system with respect to the development of TAFE. I also note that, so far as I am concerned, the Howard government’s ideological approach is going to undermine progress made at a workplace level with respect to skill related career recognition, multiskilling, a desire to reduce the number of classifications through new training arrangements and new work methods to create a more productive work force. I suggest that the Commonwealth should take a step back. The funding will go through as a result of the opposition’s support for the bill before the House, but we ought to think through some of the announcements made on the run during the election campaign and by media release with respect to the abolition of ANTA after the election-something that we did not find out about during the election campaign. There is a capacity to bring the nation together on the skilling front. State and territory governments, in association with the private sector, want to do the right thing by their local communities. I simply say that the government’s proposal to abolish ANTA and create 24 national technical colleges is not going to guarantee that young people will desire to invest years of their future in apprenticeships, because it is not a system that is based on good policy and it is not a system that has general community support. Alternatively, what the government should be doing is encouraging employers to do more in the private sector to fund and provide training for its existing work force and also attract young people who actually want to work in the skilling of apprentices. As the member for Werriwa said in this place yesterday, there is no more pressing area of government neglect than the underinvestment in TAFE and vocational education and training. We have to get this sector working effectively and efficiently. We have to properly fund our existing TAFE system and we have to get the private sector to play its part in funding and accepting its responsibility to train people. I reject the view of the government expressed yesterday that the answer to our skilling problems is migration. The answer to our skilling problems, which result from our own community failings in recent decades, is to invest in the skilling of our own work force and also to work to make apprenticeships more attractive. I therefore commend the bill to the House in terms of the additional funding and willingness to actually meet the needs of vocational education and industry in the foreseeable future, but I simply say to the government: have a rethink about your ill-thought-out agenda announced on the run-that is, the tool box solution to apprenticeship training in Australia-and think about investing within private and government sectors in the future. MAIN COMMITTEE I am also required to speak in the House very shortly. The basic context of the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 is entirely disgraceful. If you look at the history of vocational education and training from 1996 until now it is a disgraceful effort by this government, which has no fundamental commitment to the technical and further education system in Australia. The part it should be playing, to ensure that TAFE is remodelled and extended and to ensure that what the states put in will be matched by the Commonwealth in a way that is sufficient for the purposes of the state system, has been disgracefully underdone. In fact, looking at what is before us today, the explanatory memorandum to this bill is like a short note saying, ‘Dear Teacher, I am going to be late.’ It is just a complete joke. It says: ‘We have been having a talk with the states, but we have not made an agreement with them. We have our bargaining position, so we are going to legislate our bargaining position and say cop it or else.’ We know what the basis of this position is and the people up in the Parliamentary Library know what it is. Their brief talks about what has happened. When this government came to power in 1996 they reduced the funding agreement established by Labor by five per cent. They discontinued a five per cent real growth on base recurrent funding in 1996. What did they do in 1997-98? They compounded it. They said that annual funding to the states and territories needed to be cut to provide ‘an incentive to the states to achieve efficiency gains in their VET operations’. This reduction was estimated to be $20 million in 1998. It was to be carried into subsequent years, and so it has been. This government cares nothing about the TAFE sector. It cares nothing about technical and further education. It has proved it in 1996, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000 and then through to 2003. In 2004 they had an election, so they came up with a bright idea. They said, ‘If you have a look at what we have done, there is a bit of a problem occurring.’ There was a bit of a realisation that the traineeship program they put in place to degrade apprenticeships down to traineeships to boost the numbers and in fact to decrease the quality of the training available to young Australians was causing a bit of a problem. People were waking up to the fact that there was a significant difficulty. What did they do? They proposed to establish 24 technical high schools run by the Commonwealth under Australian Workplace Agreements. That would substitute for what they had not done in the technical and further education area. This is a national disgrace. In the last year, 250,000 people have come in from overseas to take the jobs that should be there for skilled Australians. Young people who should have access to technical and further education training that will allow them not just traineeships but to come out as fully qualified apprentices have been told effectively: ‘You need not apply. We’re not interested. What we’d rather do is get the Poms, the Irish or people from elsewhere in the world to come in, work on a four-year contract in Australia, and-guess what?-at the end of the four years, with a quarter of a million people a year added to the immigration intake, if they apply to stay in Australia we will not operate the normal immigration guidelines. What we’ll do is give them a discounted entry to Australia. They can stay here as a fully qualified plumber, carpenter or tradesman. In that way, we’ll try to fix the skills shortage.’ This government will not commit to young Australians and to their education. It has cut the recurrent funding. It has cut out any commitment to their future. It has effectively said to MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Hatton (Blaxland) (7.46 P.m.)
theText: I will be brief, which is not my usual style, becausethem, ‘You can have a deskilled future in which you can be on the margins of society.’ It is a complete and utter disgrace. How good is it to supply 24 technical high schools to provide what the whole technical and further education system has been attempting to provide? I personally think the people who wrote the Carmichael report were right when they went to Austria and other European countries and said the education systems operative there did a better job of providing skills education, training and apprenticeships. People who went to school in Austria, Germany or Holland would come out with a comprehensive education, but also in those schools-which were full technical high schools across the entire system-with an extra year of training they would come out as fully qualified tradesmen, not just in one trade but usually in two trades. A person would come out as a fully qualified electrician, able to practise, with a certificate that indicated that they had the requisite skills from day one. They would also usually have a second qualification so that if the demand was greater in one area than another they could switch; they were completely multiskilled. The government do not understand the needs of this country when it comes to the skilling of our young people-or, worse, they do not care at all. They are willing to import people and then provide through the immigration system-effectively secretly-what they will not supply through proper funding to the states. They are not willing to grasp the nettle and say that we need a renovation of the technical and further education system. They are not willing to do the hard work and say to the state governments, ‘We need to look at a complete review of education from year 7 to year 12.’ It used to be that 38 per cent of students stayed on until year 12, but a Labor government took it to in excess of 80 per cent and we are on the way to 90 per cent. We need to look at the actual needs of all those students and determine whether or not we should have a complete recast of the system so that those Australian students who want to enter trades, who want a real apprenticeship, who want real qualifications, could be supported both by the state governments and by the Commonwealth so that they get real training, real qualifications and real jobs at the end of it. What do we have instead? We have a government that says: ‘This is what we’re putting on the table. Take it or leave it. You’ve got reduced qualifications, but what we’ll wave in front of you is 24 technical high schools.’ It is a complete and utter disgrace. It betrays the aspirations and the future lives and livelihoods of every young Australian who wants to do the right thing, to work-and work hard-and gain a qualification to take themselves through. There will be other occasions when I can return to this debate. I am required in the other place to speak on health-I am told by the deputy whip that I have got a couple of minutes, so I will run on her instructions. This is a total, complete and utter betrayal of every one of those kids who goes into school in year 7 and who in the past, before we increased the amount of time they would spend at school, would normally want to come out with some reasonable expectation of being able to devote themselves to trades. In this and the last parliament, Brendan Nelson, the Minister for Education, Science and Training, has put on a show of deeply felt concern about people who want to have a go and want to get some kind of qualification. This government is rewriting history, saying that the Labor Party is not concerned with young people and their educational concerns, that the Labor Party is not concerned with what the outcomes will be and that the coalition is the friend of the worker and the friend of the person who wants to get a trade. That is complete and utter rubbish. MAIN COMMITTEE This mob do not give a damn about the future of those people, as evidenced by what is proposed in this legislation and by their version of reduced funding to the states, reduced Commonwealth input, efficiency and productivity gains and all the rest of it. They know that traineeships are worth far less than the old apprenticeships. They know that Telstra, the state rail authorities and the other main education providers in the past have left the field. They know, or should know, that Australia is effectively deskilled and the great chance that we had to provide an education system that would allow young people to train here in Australia, have an apprenticeship and be fully qualified to work within Australia or earn income for Australia overseas in Asia is gone. This government are reprehensible in their failure to properly deal with technical and further education. They have put forward a total con job not only with regard to apprenticeships and traineeships but also with regard to technical high schools. I call on them to retract the approach they have, to have a look at secondary education Australia wide and to do the right thing by young Australians by providing them with a real future, real access to apprenticeships and real access to an education system that will provide them with a guaranteed future instead of the farce that they are presented with now. Ms HALL (Shortland) (7.57 p.m.)-The Howard government’s record when it comes to vocational education and training is absolutely abysmal. Despite its much touted New Apprenticeships scheme, this government has overseen a massive increase in skills shortage. This skills shortage is having an enormous impact on industry and Australia’s ability to compete internationally.
