The Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 will provide Commonwealth grants to states and territories to support them in their role as providers and administrators of VET. These grants are for capital and recurrent purposes and are passed to ANTA for allocation amongst states and territories. They ensure the grants to the vocational education sector for the following year. It is interesting to note that this legislation does not deal with administrative changes arising from the proposed abolition of ANTA. BeforeI came down here, I was looking at the percentage of GDP that this government have given to vocational education and training. That figure as a percentage of GDP is down. It is very interesting that, day after day, we listen to the government trying to convince the Australian people that they are doing a good job, that they are there to address the skills shortage and to make sure that all Australians have the appropriate skills that they need to find work and to meet the needs of industry. But, when you take a good look at the situation, you find that that is anything but the case. Over the years I have worked in the area of employment. I have appreciated the benefits of vocational training and how it has contributed to retraining and opportunities for Australians who want to either enter the work force, re-enter the work force or maintain their employment and move along the corporate ladder or move through various occupations within whatever industry they are involved. But under this government we have seen people’s options shrink and industry has become quite concerned about skills shortages. When I start evaluating and looking at why this happens and try to work out just what level of commitment the Howard government actually has to vocational education and training, I look to its first budget. One of the first actions that it undertook was to make massive cuts to TAFE-and, I must say, TAFE has never recovered from that. It is really interesting to see that, following the election, the MAIN COMMITTEE government is now thinking of setting up in opposition to TAFE. I will be watching that very carefully. I will be monitoring these new technical colleges that the government has promised the Australian people. I will be watching very carefully to see that there is no duplication of services and that they are actually delivering-delivering to the people who are undertaking training and delivering to industry. This government’s inaction over a long period of time has resulted in this enormous skills shortage. It has created an absolute crisis within industry and it has created a crisis for those people who are looking for work. I think one of the organisations that properly is fairly supportive of the Howard government generally is the Australian Industry Group. They have done a number of studies. They have undertaken some really authoritative studies in this area, looking at the skills shortage throughout the whole of Australia and in the Hunter, which is part of my electorate. I will spend a little bit of time examining those issues. The first statement they make in the report before me, World-class skills for world-class industries: accelerating reforms to vocational education and training, is: ‘World-class industries demand a world-class training system.’ Going through this document you will see that the Australian Industry Group believe that here in Australia we have anything but a world-class training system. What we have is a training system that has been run down; we have a training system that has been degraded by this government. On the other hand, we have had growth in industries, but the training system is totally fragmented, and it has become much more fragmented under this government. There is a shortage of skilled labour across Australia and industry has identified this as an emerging problem. I noticed earlier that the Chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment and Workplace Relations referred to an inquiry that that committee has been undertaking into workplace participation. As a member of that committee I have been privileged to take evidence throughout the whole of Australia. A common theme throughout that committee’s deliberations, submissions and hearings has been the skills shortage and the fact that on the one hand you have a skills shortage and on the other hand you have people who want to train but cannot link into the appropriate training. When you link that to the ageing of our population and some of the assumptions that have been made in that area, I think that we have a real problem unless the government truly embraces the need to address this skills shortage and the crisis that exists in Australia today. I looked through the DEWR skilled vacancy index for 2003-04 to see some of the areas where there is a skills shortage, some of the occupations where vacancies cannot be filled. It shows that there has been a 21 per cent increase in vacancies in the metal trades, a 38 per cent increase in the electrical and electronic trades, a 45 per cent increase in the printing trades and a 17.9 per cent increase in the construction trade. The sad fact is that many of these vacancies are not being filled because of a lack of people within our work force who have the appropriate skills. This is purely and simply a result of the government’s inaction in this area. It is also appropriate to put on the record that there has been an 8.9 per cent increase in vacancies in the past 12 months. In the Hunter region, 61 companies reported a total of 805 vacancies in 2004, 85 per cent of the companies surveyed were experiencing skills shortages-that is quite a considerable skills shortage-and 633 vacancies recorded were at trade level and above. What is needed is more than rhetoric. What is needed is a government that is prepared to address this issue. MAIN COMMITTEE There are also many anomalies in the training system. Constituents have visited me with their children-young people who have been unable to gain entry to appropriate training courses because the number of training courses has shrunk. In two cases that I can think of off the top of my head, parents have brought to me their sons and daughters who have undertaken training at, say, a certificate level III course. There has been a problem with an employer and, because these young people have undertaken training for a certain period of time, they have been ineligible to undertake any other apprenticeship training. This created real hardship for these young people, it created real heartache for their families, and it really limited their vocational options and their work options. It is a flaw in the system, which this government has failed to address and which I have detailed much more thoroughly in previous speeches in this House. When we are looking to address skills shortages, we have to look at them from the perspectives of the industries and of the people who would like to work in those industries. I do not think that is happening at the moment. I will focus on the Hunter for a short time. Regional industries face many challenges and opportunities in the years ahead. Traditionally, the Hunter has been a region where industries have been established because it has been seen as an area with a highly skilled work force. But, unfortunately, in recent times this has changed and the skills base of the work force has dissipated. That is very sad, because I know that there are a lot of young people in the Hunter who would be more than happy to undertake training in the trades. When I was working in that area, of all the young male students who had left at the end of year 10 or year 12 with a strong desire to undertake an apprenticeship, very few were able to obtain that much sought after apprenticeship. Similarly, for young women keen to obtain apprenticeships in areas such as hairdressing there were not the opportunities for them to undertake the training. The government needs to address this issue. As I was saying, it has been three years since there has been an emergence of a shortage of skilled labour with Hunter employers. This has impacted on their ability to tender for contracts. They would have been able to tender if there was a skilled labour force in the area. As I mentioned earlier, there are a total of 805 skilled vacancies. That is for 61 employers who currently employ 6,400 people within the Hunter region. That represents a vacancy for every eight employees in the work force. That is really significant. There are positions for electricians, boilermakers, fabricators, labourers and engineers. All these positions remain unfilled. They cannot find applicants who have the right skills, the right qualifications or the right experience to meet the needs of industry. From my perspective, that is a missed opportunity. It is a missed opportunity for the employers; a missed opportunity for the people who could be filling those vacancies; a missed opportunity for the Hunter, which concerns me very much; and a missed opportunity for Australia, which concerns me even more. It is also interesting to break up those vacancies and take it a little bit further. The skilled vacancies are higher in the smaller firms-that is, firms with 30 or fewer employees. They have a vacancy for every four members of their work force. That is really significant: four employees, one vacancy. It is very worrying. Medium sized firms have one vacancy for every six employees. Larger firms, with 100 employees or more, have one vacancy for every 10 employees. Employers are not receiving the applications. Those who do apply do not have the appropriate skill levels or the appropriate qualifications. The one thing that is constant MAIN COMMITTEE throughout this is that there is a skills gap within the existing work force. This is a real problem for industry in the Hunter region. It is also a real problem for Australia. Australia is part of a global economy. As such, if we want to succeed, if Australia really wants to embrace this global economy, we must have a highly skilled work force. We need people who can work in industry and who can perform at the highest level. Almost every firm in the Hunter is identifying gaps where they would like to employ people, gaps in training programs and gaps in their existing work force. That is of great concern to me, and I know from the deliberations of the committee that I have been a part of that the Hunter is no different from other areas within Australia. What really worries me is that all we receive from the government are platitudes. We do not receive action. We do not have the kinds of responses that will really develop benefits for all those fine industries and employers in the Hunter and throughout Australia. We also do not have the kinds of responses that will deliver jobs and outcomes to all those workers who would desperately like to work in industry. We need long-term solutions to address these skills problems. We need to encourage industry to take on more apprentices and we need to have the capacity for those apprentices to be trained. That capacity has been significantly dissipated by the government’s cuts to TAFE and to vocational education. As I have already stated, the percentage of GDP that is going to vocational training has decreased dramatically under this government. We need more apprenticeship training. We need more pre-apprenticeship training too. Employers really love pre-apprenticeship training schemes because they actually get apprentices who have got the skills to work in the workplace when they start working. We need increased financial incentives for employers, we need targeted recruitment and we need programs put in place that will allow more workplace training. What we really need, more than anything, is a government with a bit of imagination. We need a government that is committed to Australia, committed to industry and committed to providing quality training to young Australians, to Australians in the work force and to older workers. We need a government that embraces lifetime learning and puts Australia first. We need a government that puts Australian industry first and is not mean spirited but is broad minded and forward thinking. ister Assisting the Prime Minister) (8.16 p.m.)-in reply-I am delighted to follow the member for Shortland and remind her that contributions to the states and territories have risen from $777.9 million under the Australian Labor Party-her party-to $1.13 billion under this government in this calendar year. That is an increase of 45 per cent, and in real terms is an increase of 23 per cent. The Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 in fact indexes the base further to make it $1.154 billion that we are putting out to the states and territories under our vocational education funding agreement. This is about making certain that the money continues to flow. We see the contribution which is offered through this bill to the states and territories as important. We would have liked to do more. We wish we had been able to get agreement between the states and territories and the Commonwealth in 2003, because there would be many more tens of thousands of people in trade training circumstances if we had been able to get that agreement up. But without agreement the funds continue to flow-it is an undertaking that Minister Nelson and I MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004

speaker: Mr Hardgrave (Moreton
theText: Minister for Vocational and Technical Education and Mingave to the state training and education ministers as recently as just a week and a half ago. Perhaps that news has failed to filter through, in what is an uneasy time between the federal Labor Party caucus and the rest of the Australian Labor Party around the country. Mr Deputy Speaker Wilkie, as you realise, a strong economy is driving an enormous amount of jobs growth. We have gone from a position under the previous government, where kids were looking for jobs and were going through the debilitating process of not being able to find employment, to this amazing circumstance where there are jobs looking for kids. In my own electorate of MoretonI am amazed at how many businesses are now saying: ‘Juniors required. Please apply within.’ The signs stay up, not for a day but often for weeks, waiting for someone who is actually available to take that job. That is where strong economic growth has delivered for the average Australian and the average family. As a government, we want to make sure that the workers in those circumstances are well trained and have the opportunity to get access to what is regarded as world’s best practice in the area of vocational and technical education. This underpins Australia’s ability to compete in an increasingly global market environment. It is absolutely vital to ensure our continued economic growth and the continued prosperity of this country. As a government, we are committed to vocational education and training. It is shown by the significant funding that is being provided through this bill, and I thank the opposition for its support. As well, of course, through the election campaign well over $1 billion of initiatives were announced, and they will be delivered through the budget next year. These initiatives address skills shortages and some of the particular needs of young apprentices and their employers in order not only to get them in a trade and help them with the equipment they need-the tools for that trade-but also to ensure that they stay and do not drop out of their apprenticeships as, tragically, some young people do. The drop-out rate is not as high as the one in three who leave university, but it is nevertheless a significant factor. So we want to target some of those, and we are. In 2004-05 this government will spend a total of $2.1 billion on vocational education and training, of which more than $725 million will go to supporting new apprenticeships through direct incentives to employers and through the network of 500 new apprenticeship centres, the NACs. We have also announced new measures in our election commitments with a total value of $1.06 billion over four years. This is without doubt one of the most significant boosts to vocational and technical education ever undertaken by any government. The Prime Minister’s appointment of a minister to target this particular area of vital economic importance further demonstrates the high priority that he and indeed the government place on meeting the skills needs of industry. I am greatly honoured to have the opportunity to do that and to talk to people in regions around Australia, such as the Hunter. I will be there talking to industry, because industry is contacting us. TAFE training providers, private training providers and schools are contacting us and expressing an interest in being part of the network of Australian technical colleges. I hope the member for Shortland and her colleagues on that side of the chamber encourage people to participate fully in the development of what will be centres of excellence that will say to students studying in years 11 and 12 that having a trade skill outcome from their years of education is as good as-and I would argue in fact better than-any university degree. University degrees are terrific things to achieve but we need people with trade skills in situ MAIN COMMITTEE today. Those people are in the strongest position in our economy. We need to keep investing in them. The vocational education and training sector is now in this transitional stage of national arrangements. On 22 October the Prime Minister announced the abolition of the Australian National Training Authority, ANTA, and the transfer of its functions to my department from July 2005. I want to pay tribute to ANTA. It was established in 1992 to coordinate the levels of government in setting up a truly national vocational education and training system. Of course, a dozen years later, with industry leadership, this national system is in place. It is a significant achievement of ANTA and indeed all the stakeholders in the national training system that we are now delivering industry endorsed, internationally renowned and nationally recognised qualifications that certainly are the envy of many other countries around the world. The transfer of the ANTA functions to the department acknowledges the maturity of the system that has been created. It acknowledges the achievements of the national training system to date. It does not mean that there is going to be any reduction in effort-in fact, quite the opposite. The Prime Minister has announced that a new ministerial council will be established and this will ensure the continuing harmonisation of a national system of standards, of assessment and of accreditation. This will allow a clearer focus on the critical issues which are facing our country, such as the skills shortages that all speakers in this debate have talked about. I want to stress that the government have a very clear intention. We want this national system to continue and we want industry’s central role to be maintained and indeed enhanced in what lies ahead. In recognition of industry’s role in the vocational education and training sector, the Howard government will establish the Australian Institute for Trade Skill Excellence. This institute will provide industry endorsement of qualifications provided by both private and public training providers. This institute will identify high-quality and industry relevant training. The strength of Australia’s economy has seen a strong increase in demand for skilled workers. As I said, for too long success in Australian society seems to have been measured for years 11 and 12 by getting a university degree. We want to make sure that young people making decisions about what to do next are as committed as we are to challenging the view that the new apprenticeships and vocational education are somehow second-best to university. We want to continue to provide even higher quality alternatives to the 70 per cent of Australia’s young people who do not go on to university. With the establishment of the 24 Australian technical colleges in regions all around Australia, regions which need an enhancement of the skills base, we will provide pride and excellence in the teaching and acquiring of trade and craft skills at the secondary school level. These colleges will provide tuition for up to 7,200 students in years 11 and 12 and will offer both an academic and a vocational education outcome. We want to make sure that, at the end of that year 12 experience, having attended an Australian technical college a student can still make the choices they make today. But we hope that, having been immersed in a vocational and technical education sector along the way, most, if not all, will take the path of a trade skill outcome. I want to again emphasise, as I had to in the House of Representatives chamber today-and I am happy to keep doing this until those opposite abandon the negativity in opposition for MAIN COMMITTEE opposition’s sake and adopt a more positive approach-that these Australian technical colleges are not going to bypass or duplicate existing institutions. Rather, it is all about the Australian technical colleges working with existing education and training providers, developing new opportunities for young people interested in a career in the trades. The government will also provide greater financial assistance to new apprentices in skill shortage trades by offering a Commonwealth Trade Learning Scholarship and providing tool kits. The Youth Allowance will be extended to new apprentices, and third-year apprentices living away from home will be eligible for residential assistance. I think this parliament has reason to be very proud of the excellent achievements of the Australian vocational education and training systems. Since coming to power, this government has set upon a course of reinvigorating the national training system. Those opposite should be interested to know this: the latest figures show that in 2003 there were more than 1.7 million students in vocational education and training. This represents more than 12 per cent of Australia’s working-age population. That is an increase of 35 per cent over 1995’s figures. I know those opposite want to talk it down, but the facts are getting in the way of their continuous story. The numbers for new apprenticeships have grown to around 400,000 in training-nearly three times the numbers that were in training in 1995, when the figure was about 140,000. Today new apprenticeships are available in more than 500 occupations, including emerging industries such as aeroskills, electrotechnology, information technology and telecommunications. In fact, the report by the National Centre for Vocational Education Research which was released just last Friday highlights that new apprenticeship commencements in trade and related occupations have in fact increased by 18 per cent, with an estimated 66,900 commencements in the 12 months to 30 June this year. New apprenticeships in electrotechnology are up 21 per cent; in construction they are up 15 per cent; in hairdressing they are up 23 per cent; and in the automotive retail, service and repair industry they are up 12 per cent. These are all areas of skill shortages, all areas which the government is focusing on. The Australian Industry Group described these figures as ‘some of the best news heard in this area for some time’. The Ai Group is correct in stating that this government has made addressing skill shortages ‘a major priority’. That is what is really going on, but if you listened to those opposite you would never know about it. Since 1996 the number of women in vocational education and training has grown by 33 per cent, to reach some 834,400 people. That is about 42 per cent of total new apprentices in recent years. Australians of all ages are benefiting from this government’s constant and successful vocational education and training policies. Last year more than 200,000 senior secondary students enrolled in vocational education courses, reflecting the outstanding success of the VET in Schools programs, which are now available to more than 95 per cent of Australia’s secondary schools. At the same time, older people are also very well represented in vocational education and training. In 2003, 30 per cent of all VET students were aged 40 years and over. SoI am astonished by any negativity from those opposite in the face of the statistical underpinning of the government’s argument in favour of this legislation. I am pleased to inform members that my colleague Minister Nelson has written to state ministers on behalf of the government offering them certainty of funding for the whole of 2005, which will be maintained at the real value of funding in 2004. This bill will provide that MAIN COMMITTEE certainty. Funding for the first six months of 2005 has been offered under a rollover of the current ANTA agreement and funding for the second six months of the calendar year to come will be conditional on the acceptance by the states and territories of the new Commonwealthstate funding agreement that will be developed early next year. This bill appropriates funding for the full 12 months, enabling the states and territories to plan their ongoing vocational education training and delivery. Members opposite have raised matters to do with the purchase of VET priority places. These places were initiated in 2004 when the states and territories did not sign up to the agreement for 2004-06. Through my department this funding will continue in 2005 and, of course, it can be incorporated in the new Commonwealth-state funding agreement if this decision is taken with the state and territory governments. I thank all who have contributed to this debate and I note the interest of a lot of members in this area. From the government’s point of view, we are very pleased to see the Australian Labor Party, the workers party, becoming interested again in training issues. I commend the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 to the House. Question agreed to. Bill read a second time. Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation announced. Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment. Main Committee adjourned at 8.33 p.m. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Vocational Education And Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004
